sen.j: 江戸（えど,日本語以外ではEdo、Yedo、Yeddo、Yendo、Jedoなど諸表記あり）は、東京の旧称である。
sen.e: "Edo" (also described as Yedo, Yeddo, Yendo, Jedo) is the old name for Tokyo.
"Edo" (also described as Yedo, Yeddo, Yendo, Jedo) is the former name for Tokyo.
sen.cmt: Diction -- really a matter of preference.
sen.e: "Edo" (also described as Yedo, Yeddo, Yendo, Jedo) is the former name for Tokyo.

sen.j: 特に、江戸城を中心とする現在で言う東京特別区中心部（東京都千代田区・中央区 (東京都)周辺）を指す。
sen.e: It especially referred to the area centering on the Edo Castle, the current central area of Tokyo Special Ward (Chiyoda and Chuo Wards and their surrounding areas).
It refers to an area centered around Edo Castle that encompasses the center of present day Tokyo Special Ward (Chiyoda and Chuo Wards and their surrounding areas).
It refers to an area centered around Edo Castle that encompasses the center of present day Tokyo Special Ward (Chiyoda and Chuo Wards and their surrounding areas).

sen.j: 江戸は明治維新により東京とされるまで皇居を置かなかったため都ではなかったが、江戸時代には江戸幕府が置かれた事実上の日本の首都(行政首都)であり、日本の政治経済の中心地として発展した。
sen.e: Until the Meiji Restoration, when Edo was renamed Tokyo, Edo was not an official capital city because the Imperial Palace was not located in Edo, but as a matter of practice, Edo had been served as an administrative capital of Japan and developed as the center of Japanese politics and economy since a feudal government was established in Edo in the Edo Period.

Edo did not become the capital until the Meiji Restoration when it was renamed Tokyo because the Imperial Palace was not located there; However, Edo served as the seat of Bakufu authority and thus the defacto capital of Japan (administrative capital) in the Edo period, and developed into a political and economic center of power.

Edo did not become the capital until the Meiji Restoration when it was renamed Tokyo because the Imperial Palace was not located there; However, Edo served as the seat of Bakufu authority and thus the defacto capital of Japan (administrative capital) in the Edo period, and developed into a political and economic center of power.

sen.j: また、江戸城は徳川氏の征夷大将軍の居城であり、江戸は幕府の政庁が置かれる行政府の所在地であると同時に、自身も天領を支配する領主である徳川氏（徳川将軍家）の城下町でもあった。
sen.e: The Edo Castle was the residence of successive Tokugawa shoguns, aka. Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), while Edo was where bakufu (feudal government) was established along with all the government offices, and it also was a castle town (a town created around the castle of a feudal lord) of the Tokugawa clan (the Tokugawa Shogunate Family) who was the feudal lord of shogunal demesne in Edo.

The Edo Castle was the residence of successive Tokugawa shoguns, or Seii taishogun (literally, "the great general who pacifies barbarians"), and the city of Edo was both the site of bakufu administrative organs and the personal castle town of the Tokugawa Clan that ruled over the shogunal domain.

The Edo Castle was the residence of successive Tokugawa shoguns, or Seii taishogun (literally, "the great general who pacifies barbarians"), and the city of Edo was both the site of bakufu administrative organs and the personal castle town of the Tokugawa Clan that ruled over the shogunal domain.

sen.j: 幕末になると政治的中心が再び京都に移り、15代将軍徳川慶喜は将軍としては江戸に一度も居住しなかった。
sen.e: However, at the end of the Edo Period, the political center was returned to Kyoto, and therefore, the 15th shogun, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, did not reside in Edo as a shogun even once.
The political center had shifted back to Kyoto by the end of the Edo Period, and the 15th shogun TOKUGAWA Yoshinobu never resided in EDO.
The political center had shifted back to Kyoto by the end of the Edo Period, and the 15th shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA never resided in EDO.
sen.cmt: TOKUGAWA YoshinobuをYoshinobu TOKUGAWAに修正しました。

sen.j: 1868年（明治元年）に発せられた江戸ヲ称シテ東京ト為スノ詔書により江戸は東京と改称され、続く天皇の東京行幸により江戸城が東京の皇居とされた。
sen.e: In 1868 (the first year of the Meiji Period), Edo was renamed Tokyo in accordance with the promulgated imperial edict, followed by the Emperor's visit to Edo and the appointment of the Edo Castle the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.
In 1868 (the first year of the Meiji Period), Edo was renamed Tokyo in accordance with an imperial edict, and Edo Castle became the Imperial Palace in Tokyo after the Emperor's arrival.
In 1868 (the first year of the Meiji Period), Edo was renamed Tokyo in accordance with an imperial edict, and Edo Castle became the Imperial Palace in Tokyo after the Emperor's arrival.

sen.j: 翌年には明治新政府も京都から東京に移され、日本の事実上の首都となる。
sen.e: In the following year, all the functions of the new Meiji government were moved to Tokyo from Kyoto, paving the way for Tokyo to officially become the capital city of Japan.
In the following year, all of the functions of the new Meiji government were transferred to Tokyo from Kyoto, paving the way for Tokyo to become the capital city of Japan.
In the following year, all of the functions of the new Meiji government were transferred to Tokyo from Kyoto, paving the way for Tokyo to become the capital city of Japan.

sen.j: また、東京への改称とともに町奉行支配地内を管轄する東京府庁が開庁された（1871年、廃藩置県に伴い新・東京府に更置）。
sen.e: Also, to coincide with the renaming of Edo, Tokyo-fucho (Tokyo prefectural office) was established to take over the governance of the area the town magistrate once ruled (in 1871, Tokyo-fu (Tokyo Prefecture) was re-established in accordance with the Haihan-chiken system [abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures]).

Along with the renaming of Tokyo to Edo, the Tokyo-fucho (Tokyo prefectural office) was established to govern the town magistrate (In 1871, Tokyo-fu (Tokyo Prefecture) was re-established in accordance with the Haihan-chiken system [Abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures]).

Along with the renaming of Tokyo to Edo, the Tokyo-fucho (Tokyo prefectural office) was established to govern the town magistrate (In 1871, Tokyo-fu (Tokyo Prefecture) was re-established in accordance with the Haihan-chiken system [Abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures]).

sen.j: 1889年に、市制施行で東京市となった。
sen.e: In 1889, Tokyo-shi (Tokyo City) was established based on the municipal organization.
In 1889, Tokyo-shi (Tokyo City) was established in accordance to munipal organization.
In 1889, Tokyo-shi (Tokyo City) was established in accordance to municipal organization.

sen.j: 1943年の戦時体制下で、東京府と東京市は廃止されて、東京都が設置された。
sen.e: In 1943, when Japan was under the wartime regime, Tokyo-fu and Tokyo-shi were both abolished and Tokyo-to (Tokyo Metropolis) was established.
Under the wartime governance in 1943, Tokyo-fu and Tokyo-shi were both abolished, and Tokyo-to (Tokyo Metropolis) was established in their place.
Under the wartime governance in 1943, Tokyo-fu and Tokyo-shi were both abolished, and Tokyo-to (Tokyo Metropolis) was established in their place.

sen.j: 江戸の町は、大きく分けて見ると江戸城の西に広がる山の手の武家屋敷と、東の隅田川をはじめとする数々の河川・堀に面した庶民の町（下町）に大別される。
sen.e: The town of Edo was largely divided into two areas; an uptown area in the west of the Edo Castle, where samurai resided, and a downtown area developed along various rivers including Sumida-gawa River and moats, where common people lived.

The town of Edo was roughly categorized into an uptown area west of Edo Castle where samurai lived, and a downtown (shitamachi) area facing several rivers and moats beginning with the Sumidagawa riverwhere commoners lived.

The town of Edo was roughly categorized into an uptown area west of Edo Castle where samurai lived, and a downtown (shitamachi) area facing several rivers and moats beginning with the Sumidagawa riverwhere commoners lived.

sen.j: 川・堀の水路網と蔵は江戸を象徴する町並の特徴であり、蔵造りの町並が残された川越市、栃木市、佐原市などの関東地方の河港都市は、江戸に似た構造という点や江戸と交流が深かったという点から「小江戸」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: Channel networks of rivers and moats and kura (the earthen-walled storehouses) are the typical townscape of Edo, and the areas which still have the beautiful scenery of kura, such as Kawagoe City, Tochigi City and Sawara City, all of which are river port cities in the Kanto region, are now commonly called 'small Edo' for their resemblance to Edo in terms of the city structure and also for the active exchange they had with Edo in the past.

Channel networks of rivers and moats and kura (the earthen-walled storehouses) characterized the Edo cityscape, and those river port cities in the Kanto area where the kura cityscape have survived such as Kawagoe, Tochigi, and Sawara are called "small Edo" for their architectural resemblance to Edo and the fact that these cities were actively traded with Edo.

Channel networks of rivers and moats and kura (the earthen-walled storehouses) characterized the Edo cityscape, and those river port cities in the Kanto area where the kura cityscape have survived such as Kawagoe, Tochigi, and Sawara are called "small Edo" for their architectural resemblance to Edo and the fact that these cities were actively traded with Edo.

tit.e: Edo before the arrival of the Tokugawa clan
Edo prior to the arrival of the Tokugawa clan
Edo prior to the arrival of the Tokugawa clan

sen.j: 「江戸」という地名は、鎌倉幕府の歴史書『吾妻鏡』が史料上の初見で、おおよそ平安時代後半に発生した地名であると考えられている。
sen.e: The name 'Edo' first appeared in "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), a history book of the Kamakura-bakufu feudal government (c.1185 - 1333), but it is considered that the establishment of Edo dates back to the latter half of the Heian Period (794 - c.1185).

The first written record pertaining to the name 'Edo' first appeared in "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), a Kamakura-bakufu (c.1185 - 1333) history, but the name itself is said to be a place name that emerged in the latter half of the Heian Period (794 - c.1185).

The first written record pertaining to the name 'Edo' first appeared in "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), a Kamakura-bakufu (c.1185 - 1333) history, but the name itself is said to be a place name that emerged in the latter half of the Heian Period (794 - c.1185).

sen.j: 地名の語源は諸説あるが、江は川あるいは入江とすると、戸は入口を意味するから「江の入り口」に由来したと考える説が有力である。
sen.e: Although there are many theories on the etymology of the place name, the widely-accepted one is that 'Edo' means 'the entrance of a river or a cove', as 'E' means a river or a cove and 'Do' means an entrance.

Although there are many theories on the etymology of the Edo as a place name, the theory that the Character "e" [江] refers to a river or mouth of a river, and "to" [戸] as a gate or theshhold and hence "entry to a river" has been widely accepted.

Although there are many theories on the etymology of the Edo as a place name, the theory that the Character "e" [江] refers to a river or mouth of a river, and "to" [戸] as a gate or theshhold and hence "entry to a river" has been widely accepted.

sen.j: 当時の江戸は、武蔵国と下総国の国境である隅田川の河口の西に位置し、日比谷入江と呼ばれる入江が、後の江戸城の間近に入り込んでいた。
sen.e: Indeed, Edo at that time was located in the west of the estuary of Sumida-gawa River which served as a provincial border between Musashi Province and Shimosa Province, and Hibiya cove stretched close to the place where the Edo Castle was constructed in later years.

Indeed, Edo was established west of the Sumidagawa River estuary which served as a provincial border between Musashi Province and Shimosa Province, and Hibiya inlet stretched across the area where the Edo Castle was later constructed.

Indeed, Edo was established west of the Sumidagawa River estuary which served as a provincial border between Musashi Province and Shimosa Province, and Hibiya inlet stretched across the area where the Edo Castle was later constructed.

sen.j: 江戸の開発は、平安時代後期に武蔵国の秩父地方から出て川越市から入間川 (埼玉県)（現荒川 (関東)）沿いに平野部へと進出してきた桓武平氏を称する秩父党の一族によって始められた。
sen.e: The development of Edo was initiated in late Heian Period by a family of the Chichibu party, Kanmu-Heishi (the Taira clan), who entered flatlands from the Chichibu region of Musashi Province through Kawagoe City by advancing along Iruma-gawa River (present-day, Ara-kawa River in the Kanto region).

Edo was founded in the late Heian Period by a clan of the Chichibu party that claimed the name of Kanmu-Heishi (the Taira clan) who entered the plains along the Irumagawa River ((Saitama Prefecture) (Present-day Arakawa (Kanto)) from Kawagoe City from the Chichibu region of Musashi province.

Edo was founded in the late Heian Period by a clan of the Chichibu party that claimed the name of Kanmu-Heishi (the Taira clan) who entered the plains along the Irumagawa River ((Saitama Prefecture) (Present-day Arakawa (Kanto)) from Kawagoe City from the Chichibu region of Musashi province.

sen.j: 11世紀に秩父氏から出た江戸重継は、江戸の桜田（のちの江戸城）の高台に居館を構え、江戸の地名をとって江戸太郎を称し、江戸氏を興す。
sen.e: In the 11th century, Shigetsugu of the Chichibu clan built his own residence (later, the Edo Castle) on the hill of Sakurada, and founded the EDO clan by renaming himself Taro EDO after the area name, Edo.

In the 11th century, Shigetsugu of the Chichibu clan built his own residence (later, the Edo Castle) on a hill overlooking Sakurada, and founded the EDO clan by renaming himself EDO Taro after the place name Edo.

In the 11th century, Shigetsugu of the Chichibu clan built his own residence (later, the Edo Castle) on a hill overlooking Sakurada, and founded the EDO clan by renaming himself EDO Taro after the place name Edo.

sen.j: 重継の子である江戸重長は1180年に源頼朝が挙兵した時には、当初は伊勢平氏方として頼朝方の三浦氏と戦ったが、後に和解して鎌倉幕府の御家人となった。
sen.e: When MINAMOTO no Yoritomo raised an army in 1180, Shigenaga EDO, the son of Shigetsugu, first took the side of Ise-Heishi (the Taira clan) and fought against the Miura clan of the Yoritomo side, but later switched sides to Yoritomo and became a gokenin (shogunal retainers) of Kamakura bakufu (headed by Yoritomo).

When MINAMOTO no Yoritomo raised an army in 1180, EDO Shigenaga, the son of Shigetsugu, initially fought against the Miura clan that was allied to Yoritomo as an ally of Ise-Heishi (Taira Clan), but later made peace with the Yoritomo and became a gokenin (shogunal retainers) of Kamakura bakufu (headed by Yoritomo).

When MINAMOTO no Yoritomo raised an army in 1180, EDO Shigenaga, the son of Shigetsugu, initially fought against the Miura clan that was allied to Yoritomo as an ally of Ise-Heishi (Taira Clan), but later made peace with the Yoritomo and became a gokenin (shogunal retainers) of Kamakura bakufu (headed by Yoritomo).

sen.j: 弘長元年10月3日 (旧暦)（1261年）、江戸氏の一族の一人であった地頭江戸長重が正嘉の飢饉による荒廃で経営ができなくなった江戸郷前島村（現在の東京駅周辺）を北条氏得宗家に寄進した。
sen.e: According to records, Nagashige EDO, who was a member of the Edo clan and held a post of jito (manager and lord of manor) donated to the Tokuso family of the HOJO clan the Maeshima Village of Edo-go (present-day, the area surrounding the Tokyo Station) in 1261, because the area was destroyed and went out of control by the Shoka Famine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to historical records, EDO Nagashige, who was a member of the Edo clan and held the post of jito (manager and lord of manor) donated Maeshima Village of Edo-go (Area around present-day Tokyo Station) to the Tokuso family in 1261, because the area became ruined and unmanageable due to famine.

According to historical records, Nagashige EDO, who was a member of the Edo clan and held the post of jito (manager and lord of manor) donated Maeshima Village of Edo-go (Area around present-day Tokyo Station) to the Tokuso family in 1261, because the area became ruined and unmanageable due to famine.
sen.cmt: EDO NagashigeをNagashige EDOに修正島地亜。

sen.j: 長重はその被官となり、1315年までに得宗家から円覚寺に再寄進されていることが記録として残されている。
sen.e: Nagashige became a retainer of the Tokuso family, and the land was again donated to Enkaku-ji Shrine by the family before 1315.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Historical records reveal that Nagashige became a retainer of the Tokuso family, and the land was again donated to Enkaku-ji Shrine by the family before 1315.
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; Continuity with the previous sentence.
sen.e: Historical records reveal that Nagashige became a retainer of the Tokuso family, and the land was again donated to Enkaku-ji Shrine by the family before 1315.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府が滅びると、江戸氏は南北朝時代 (日本)の騒乱において初め新田義貞に従って南朝 (日本)方につき、後に北朝 (日本)に帰順して鎌倉公方に仕えた。
sen.e: After Kamakura bakufu collapsed and the turmoil of the Northern and Southern Imperial Courts begun, the Edo clan first took the side of the Southern Court by following the order of Yoshisada NITTA, but later switched sides to the Northern Court and served Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of the Kanto region).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: With the collapse of the Kamakura bakufu and the ensuing turmoil of the Northern and Southern Court Period, the Edo clan initially allied itself to the Southern Court serving NITTA Yoshisada, but later changed allegiances to the Northern Court and served as the Kamakura Kubo (Governor-general of the Kanto region).
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; Capitalizing Titles; Reversing Name Order
sen.e: With the collapse of the Kamakura bakufu and the ensuing turmoil of the Northern and Southern Court Period, the Edo clan initially allied itself to the Southern Court serving Yoshisada NITTA, but later changed allegiances to the Northern Court and served as the Kamakura Kubo (Governor-general of the Kanto region).
sen.cmt: NITTA YoshisadaをYoshisada NITTAに修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、室町時代に次第に衰え、本拠地を多摩郡喜多見（現在の東京都世田谷区喜多見）に移した。
sen.e: However, in the Muromachi Period, the power of the Edo clan waned, forcing the clan to relocate its base to Kitami of Tama County (present-day, Kitami, Setagaya Ward, Tokyo Metropolis).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the power of the EDO clan gradually waned throughout the Muromachi Period, prompting it to relocate to Kitami of Tama County (Present-day, Kitami, Setagaya Ward, Tokyo Metropolis).
However, the power of the EDO clan gradually waned throughout the Muromachi Period, prompting it to relocate to Kitami of Tama County (Present-day, Kitami, Setagaya Ward, Tokyo Metropolis).

sen.j: 代わって江戸の地には、関東管領上杉氏の一族扇谷上杉家の有力な武将であり家老であった太田資長（のちの太田道灌）が入り、江戸氏の居館跡に江戸城を築く。
sen.e: In place of the Edo clan, Sukenaga OTA (later, Dokan OTA), a powerful military commander and chief retainer of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi clan (a branch family of the Uesugi clan, Kanto Kanrei [shogunal deputy for the Kanto region]), entered Edo and built the Edo Castle based on the residence of the Edo clan.

OTA Sukenaga (later, OTA Dokan), a powerful military commander and chief retainer of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi clan (a branch family of the Uesugi clan, Kanto Kanrei [shogunal deputy for the Kanto region]) entered Edo and built the Edo Castle over the site of the former residence of the Edo clan.
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; switching name order; Spelling mistake in word bank
sen.e: Sukenaga OTA (later, Dokan OTA), a powerful military commander and chief retainer of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi clan (a branch family of the Uesugi clan, Kanto Kanrei [shogunal deputy for the Kanto region]) entered Edo and built the Edo Castle over the site of the former residence of the Edo clan.
sen.cmt: OTA SukenagaをSukenaga OTAに修正しました。OTA DokanをDokan OTAに修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸城は、一説には長禄2年（1456年）に建設を始め、翌年完成したという。
sen.e: According to one theory, the construction of the Edo Castle started in 1456 and completed in the following year.
According to one theory, the construction of the Edo Castle began in 1456 and was completed in the following year.
According to one theory, the construction of the Edo Castle began in 1456 and was completed in the following year.

sen.j: 太田資長は文明 (日本)10年（1478年）に剃髪し道灌と号し、文明18年（1486年）に謀殺されるまで江戸城を中心に南関東一円で活躍した。
sen.e: Even after entering into priesthood in 1478 by shaving his head and calling himself Dokan, Sukenaga OTA served as a powerful lord throughout the southern Kanto region with placing its military base in the Edo Castle, until assassinated in 1486.

Even after entering into priesthood in 1478 by shaving his head and calling himself Dokan, OTA Sukenaga ruled over the southern Kanto region from his base of power in the southern Kanto region until his assasination in 1486.
sen.cmt: The original translation included details not included in the original. I am not quite sure how you can translate 活躍 as "served as a powerful lord." Japanese reading for chronology is included.
sen.e: Even after entering into priesthood in 1478 by shaving his head and calling himself Dokan, Sukenaga OTA ruled over the southern Kanto region from his base of power in the southern Kanto region until his assasination in 1486.
sen.cmt: OTA SukenagaをSukenaga OTAに修正しました。

sen.j: 道灌の時代、現在の神田川 (東京都)並びに日本橋川の前身である平川（平河）は日比谷入江に流れ込んでおり、西に日比谷入江、東に江戸湊（但し『東京市史稿』は日比谷入江を江戸湊としている）がある江戸前島周辺は中世には、浅草や品川湊と並ぶ、武蔵国の代表的な湊であった。
sen.e: Around this period of time, in Edo, Hira-kara River (present-day, Kanda-gawa River and Nihonbashi-gara River in Tokyo) poured into Hibiya cove, and the area which had Edo Maejima in the center, Hibiya cove in the west and Edo-minato Port in the east, served as an influential port of Musashi Province during the medieval period rivalling the ports of Asakusa and Shingawa. (however, in the "Tokyoshi Shiko", Hibiya cove is identified as Edo-minato Port).
sen.cmt: 道灌の時代：省略しています。
sen.e: In the time of Dokan, the Hirakawa River (present-day, Kanda-gawa River and Nihonbashi-gara River in Tokyo) poured into Hibiya inlet, and the area around Edo Maejima east of the Hibiya cove and west of the Edo-minato Port served as an influential port of Musashi Province during the medieval period rivalling the ports of Asakusa and Shingawa (however, in the "Tokyoshi Shiko", Hibiya inlet is identified as Edo-minato Port).
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes (It makes stylistic sense to locate Edo Maeshima in relation to the two locations raised, rather than vice-versa.).
sen.e: In the time of Dokan, the Hirakawa River (present-day, Kanda-gawa River and Nihonbashi-gara River in Tokyo) poured into Hibiya inlet, and the area around Edo Maejima east of the Hibiya cove and west of the Edo-minato Port served as an influential port of Musashi Province during the medieval period rivalling the ports of Asakusa and Shingawa (however, in the "Tokyoshi Shiko", Hibiya inlet is identified as Edo-minato Port).

sen.j: 江戸や品川は利根川（現在の古利根川・中川）や荒川 (関東)などの河口に近く、北関東の内陸部から水運を用いて鎌倉・小田原城・西国方面に出る際の中継地点となった。
sen.e: As Edo and Shinagawa were located close to the estuaries of Ara-kara River and Tone-gawa River (present-day, Furutone-gawa River and Naka-gawa River), they served as a relay point for water transportation from inland areas of the North Kanto region to places such as Kamakura, the Odawara Castle and to as far as the western part of Japan.

Due to their proximity to the Ara-kara River and Tone-gawa River (present-day, Furutone-gawa River and Naka-gawa River) estuaries, the ports of Edo and Shinagawa served as important hubs for riverine transportation from inland areas of the northern Kanto to places such as Kamakura and Odawara Castle, and locations as far as western parts of Japan.

Due to their proximity to the Ara-kara River and Tone-gawa River (present-day, Furutone-gawa River and Naka-gawa River) estuaries, the ports of Edo and Shinagawa served as important hubs for riverine transportation from inland areas of the northern Kanto to places such as Kamakura and Odawara Castle, and locations as far as western parts of Japan.

sen.j: 道灌の死後、扇谷上杉氏の衰亡と共に、江戸城は後北条氏の支城となった。
sen.e: After the death of Dokan and the collapse of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi clan, the Edo Castle was taken over by the Gohojo clan and used as its subsidiary castle.
After the death of Dokan and the collapse of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi clan, the Edo Castle was taken over by the Gohojo clan and used as its subsidiary castle.
After the death of Dokan and the collapse of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi clan, the Edo Castle was taken over by the Gohojo clan and used as its subsidiary castle.

sen.j: 後北条氏末期には北条氏政が直接支配して太田氏や千葉氏を統率していた。
sen.e: During the later years of the Gohojo clan, Ujimasa HOJO seized a direct control over the Castle and lead the Ota clan and the Chiba clan.
During the later years of the Gohojo clan, HOJO Ujimasa seized direct control over the castle and led the Ota clan and the Chiba clan.
sen.cmt: spelling error; unneccessary particles; unnecessary capitals; name order
sen.e: During the later years of the Gohojo clan, HOJO Ujimasa seized direct control over the castle and led the Ota clan and the Chiba clan.

sen.j: 一介の地方の城下町から巨大都市への大改造を実現した人物は、徳川家康であった。
sen.e: It was Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who transformed a local castle town into a huge metropolis.
It was TOKUGAWA Ieyasu who transformed a regional castle town into a huge metropolis.
It was Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who transformed a regional castle town into a huge metropolis.
sen.cmt: TOKUGAWA IeyasuをIeyasu TOKUGAWAに修正しました。

sen.j: 1590年、後北条氏が小田原の役で豊臣秀吉に滅ぼされると、後北条氏の旧領に封ぜられ、開拓の命を受けた徳川家康は、関東地方の中心となるべき居城を江戸に定めた。
sen.e: In 1590, when the Gohojo clan was destroyed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in the Siege of Odawara, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was assigned to oversee the territory of the Gohojo clan and to reclaim lands, designated Edo as where he would reside to oversea the Kanto region.

With the destruction of the Gohojo clan by TOYOTOMI Hideyoshi in the Siege of Odawara (1590), TOKUGAWA Ieyasu, who was assigned to govern and develop former Gohojo territories designated Edo as the central place in the Kanto region from where he would govern.

With the destruction of the Gohojo clan by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in the Siege of Odawara (1590), TOKUGAWA Ieyasu, who was assigned to govern and develop former Gohojo territories designated Edo as the central place in the Kanto region from where he would govern.

sen.j: 同年の旧暦8月1日 (旧暦)（八朔）、家康は駿府から居を移すが、当時の江戸城は老朽化した粗末な城であったという。
sen.e: In the same year, Ieyasu moved into the Edo Castle from Sunpu, but it is believed that the Edo Castle at that time was an aging, humble castle.
In the very same year, Ieyasu moved from Sunpu and took residence in Edo Castle, but it is said that Edo Castle was then an aging and humble castle.
In the very same year, Ieyasu moved from Sunpu and took residence in Edo Castle, but it is said that Edo Castle was then an aging and humble castle.

sen.j: 家康は江戸城本城の拡張は一定程度に留める代わりに城下町の建設を進め、神田山を削り、日比谷入江を盛んに埋め立てて町を広げ、家臣と町民の家屋敷を配置した。
sen.e: Instead of extending the main enclosure of the Castle more than necessary, Ieyasu promoted the construction of the Edo castle town by digging Mt. Kado and redeeming Hibiya cove to expand the area, and houses and residences were also built for his vassals and townspeople.

Ieyasu prioritized the construction of the surrounding castletown over the expansion of the main castle enclosure by levelling Mt. Kado and reclaiming the Hibiya inlet to expand the habitable areas and build residences for vassals and townspeople.

Ieyasu prioritized the construction of the surrounding castletown over the expansion of the main castle enclosure by levelling Mt. Kado and reclaiming the Hibiya inlet to expand the habitable areas and build residences for vassals and townspeople.

sen.j: 突貫工事であったために、埋め立て当初は地面が固まっておらず、乾燥して風が吹くと、もの凄い埃が舞い上がるという有様だったと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that due to the rushed construction, the redeemed area was not firm even after the completion of the work, and when a wind blew, a massive amount of dust was flying into the air.

It is said that the earth of the newly reclaimed land had not yet hardened due to the rushed nature of the reclamation project, and massive plumes of dust were blown into the air even after the earth had dried.

It is said that the earth of the newly reclaimed land had not yet hardened due to the rushed nature of the reclamation project, and massive plumes of dust were blown into the air even after the earth had dried.

sen.j: この時期の江戸城はこれまでの本丸・二ノ丸に、西丸・三ノ丸・吹上・北ノ丸があった。
sen.e: The Edo Castle in this period had not only Honmaru (a main enclosure) and Ninomaru (second bailey), but also the extended wings including Nishinomaru (west compartment), Sannomaru (third bailey), Fukiage and Kitanomaru (north compartment).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処吹上：具体的な内容が分からないため、説明していません。
sen.e: The Edo Castle in this period constituted a central Honmaru (a main enclosure) and Ninomaru (second bailey), as well as the extensions that included Nishinomaru (west compartment), Sannomaru (third bailey), Fukiage and Kitanomaru (north compartment).

The Edo Castle in this period constituted a central Honmaru (a main enclosure) and Ninomaru (second bailey), as well as the extensions that included Nishinomaru (west compartment), Sannomaru (third bailey), Fukiage and Kitanomaru (north compartment).

sen.j: また道三掘や平川の江戸前島中央部への移設、それに伴う埋め立てにより、現在の西丸下の半分以上が埋め立られている（この時期の本城といえるのはこの内、本丸・二ノ丸と家康の隠居所として造られた西丸である）。
sen.e: However, as Dosan Moat and Hira-kawa River were moved to the central area of Edo Maejima, followed by the landfill of the Moat and River, more than half of the current Nishinomaru-shimo area was a redeemed area (during this period, the main enclosure indicated Honmaru, Ninomaru, and Nishinomaru [a retreat for Ieyasu]).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Additionally, the diversion of the Dosan Moat and Hira-kawa River to the central area of Edo Maejima, and the concurrent reclamation project led to the reclamation of more than half of present-day Nishinomaru-shimo area (During this period, the main castle enclosure included Honmaru, Ninomaru, and Nishinomaru [a retreat for Ieyasu]).
sen.cmt: Diction (The rerouting of rivers and moats are referred to as diversions)
sen.e: Additionally, the diversion of the Dosan Moat and Hira-kawa River to the central area of Edo Maejima, and the concurrent reclamation project led to the reclamation of more than half of present-day Nishinomaru-shimo area (During this period, the main castle enclosure included Honmaru, Ninomaru, and Nishinomaru [a retreat for Ieyasu]).

sen.j: 家康が1600年の関ヶ原の戦いに勝利して天下人となり、1603年に征夷大将軍に任ぜられると、幕府の所在地として江戸の政治的重要性は一気に高まった。
sen.e: After Ieyasu won the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600 to become a ruler of the country and was appointed as Seii taishogun in 1603, Edo where Ieyasu had resided was turned into a place with a political significance, because the feudal government was established there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Edo rose in political prominence when it became the seat of the Bakufu government when Ieyasu 's became the ruler of Japan after his victory in the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, and was annointed "Seii taishogun" in 1603.

Edo rose in political prominence when it became the seat of the Bakufu government when Ieyasu 's became the ruler of Japan after his victory in the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, and was annointed "Seii taishogun" in 1603.

sen.j: また、徳川家に服する諸大名の屋敷が設けられ、江戸に居住する大名の家臣・家族や、徳川氏の旗本・御家人近世の御家人などの武士が数多く居住するようになるとともに、彼らの生活を支える商人・職人が流入し、町が急速に拡大した。
sen.e: Also, residences of many daimyo (feudal lords serving the Tokugawa family) were built, and a large number of daimyo's vassals and families, and shogunal bannermen and retainers moved in, followed by the influx of merchants and craftsmen who supported the lives of those people, all of which contributed to the rapid expansion of the town.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Also, residences of many daimyo (feudal lords serving the Tokugawa family) were built, and a large number of daimyo's vassals and families, and shogunal bannermen and retainers moved in, followed by the influx of merchants and craftsmen who supported the lives of those people, all of which contributed to the rapid expansion of the town.

Also, residences of many daimyo (feudal lords serving the Tokugawa family) were built, and a large number of daimyo's vassals and families, and shogunal bannermen and retainers moved in, followed by the influx of merchants and craftsmen who supported the lives of those people, all of which contributed to the rapid expansion of the town.

sen.j: 一方、江戸城とその堀が幕府から大名に課せられた普請によって整備され、江戸城は巨大な堅城に生まれ変わり、城と武家屋敷を取り巻く広大な惣構が構築された。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Edo Castle and its moats were renovated by daimyo who was assigned to labor service by the government, and the Castle was reborn as a massive, strong fortress, and expansive defensive structures were constructed to encompass the castle and samurai residences.

Meanwhile, the Edo Castle and its moats were renovated by daimyo who were consigned to labor by the government, and the castle was reborn as a massive, hardened citadel, and big defense facilities were also constructed in a way to surround the Castle and samurai residences.

Meanwhile, the Edo Castle and its moats were renovated by daimyo who were consigned to labor by the government, and the castle was reborn as a massive, hardened citadel, and big defense facilities were also constructed in a way to surround the Castle and samurai residences.

sen.j: 都市開発の歴史については後の都市の章で述べる。
sen.e: Please see the chapter of 'Metropolis' for urban development.
Please see the section on 'Metropolis' for the history of urban development.
sen.cmt: "Chapter"--> "Section" because the text may not necessarily be printed in a book
sen.e: Please see the section on 'Metropolis' for the history of urban development.

sen.j: 1657年の明暦の大火の後、再建事業によって市域は隅田川を超え、東へと拡大した。
sen.e: After the Great Fire of Meireki in 1657, reconstruction work started and the city was again expanded eastward over Sumida-gawa River.
With the reconstruction of the city after the Great Fire of Meireki in 1657, the city expanded east of the Sumida-gawa River.
With the reconstruction of the city after the Great Fire of Meireki in 1657, the city expanded east of the Sumida-gawa River.

sen.j: その人口は絶えず拡大を続け、18世紀初頭には人口が百万人を超え、八百八町といわれる世界有数（一説によると当時世界一）の大都市へと発展を遂げた。
sen.e: While the population of the town was continuously increasing, as of the beginning of the 18th century, it exceeded one million and the city became one of the biggest international metropolises with 808 towns (according to one estimate, it was the biggest in the world).

The population continued to increase, and exceeded one million at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and became known as a city of a "eight-hundred-and-eight-towns" (metaphor for an infinite towns)- one of the world's great metropolises (By some estimates, it was the most populous metropolis in the world.).

The population continued to increase, and exceeded one million at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and became known as a city of a "eight-hundred-and-eight-towns" (metaphor for an infinite towns)- one of the world's great metropolises (By some estimates, it was the most populous metropolis in the world.).

sen.j: 人口の増大は、江戸を東日本における大消費地とし、東日本各地の農村と結ばれた大市場、経済的先進地方である上方（近畿地方）と関東地方を結ぶ中継市場として、経済的な重要性も増した。
sen.e: The population increase in Edo turned the area into the biggest consuming city in eastern Japan, and Edo played a part as a relay point to link between the Kanto region, consuming area, and Kamigata (Kinki region), a big market place with connection to farming villages throughout Japan and also an economically advanced region, which helped to lift the economical stature of Edo.

Population growth in Edo turned the city into the consumption center of eastern japan, and faciliated its rise to economic prominence as a significant market that linked the farming villages of various regions of eastern Japan, and a hub market that linked the economically advanced Kamigata (Kinki region) and Kanto regions.

Population growth in Edo turned the city into the consumption center of eastern japan, and faciliated its rise to economic prominence as a significant market that linked the farming villages of various regions of eastern Japan, and a hub market that linked the economically advanced Kamigata (Kinki region) and Kanto regions.

sen.j: 当時の江戸は、『東都歳時記』、『富嶽三十六景』の「東本願寺 (東京都台東区)」など、漢風に「東都」とも呼ばれる大都市となっていた。
sen.e: Edo in this period was regarded as a huge city at home and abroad and called 'Toto' (literally, eastern capital) in Chinese style, as described in "Toto Saijiki" (Customs of the Eastern Capital) and 'Higashi Hongan-ji Temple (Taito Ward, Tokyo)' of "Fugaku Sanju Rokkei" (Thirty-six views of Mount Fuji).

By this time Edo had grown into a large metropolis was referred to in Chinese-style as 'Toto' (literally, Eastern Capital) as described in "Toto Saijiki" (Customs of the Eastern Capital) and 'Higashi Hongan-ji Temple (Taito Ward, Tokyo)' of "Fugaku Sanju Rokkei" (Thirty-six views of Mount Fuji).

By this time Edo had grown into a large metropolis was referred to in Chinese-style as 'Toto' (literally, Eastern Capital) as described in "Toto Saijiki" (Customs of the Eastern Capital) and 'Higashi Hongan-ji Temple (Taito Ward, Tokyo)' of "Fugaku Sanju Rokkei" (Thirty-six views of Mount Fuji).

sen.j: 18世紀末から19世紀初めには、上方にかわる文化的な中心地ともなり、経済活動や参勤交代を通じた江戸を中心とする人の往来は江戸から地方へ、地方から江戸へ盛んな文化の伝播をもたらした。
sen.e: From the end of the 18th century through the beginning of the 19th century, Edo was developed into a cultural center, replacing Kamigata, and traffic of people into and from Edo for economic activities and Sankinkotai (a system for feudal lords to live in Edo every other year) brought a lot of local cultures to Edo and vice versa.

From the end of the 18th century through the beginning of the 19th century, Edo surpassed Kamigata (This is a commonly used term referring to Kyoto and the Kansai region) as a cultural center, and the active traffic of people between Edo and the provinces due to economic activities and the sankinkotai (a system that required feudal lords to reside in Edo every other year) facilitated the active transmission of culture between Edo and the provinces.
sen.cmt: "上方" should not be translated alone as "kamigata"-- there should be additional information included in the parenthesis; unnecessary capitals; Please check to see if sankin kotai required feudal lords to live Edo every other years, because I believe it was every three years.
sen.e: From the end of the 18th century through the beginning of the 19th century, Edo surpassed Kamigata (This is a commonly used term referring to Kyoto and the Kansai region) as a cultural center, and the active traffic of people between Edo and the provinces due to economic activities and the sankinkotai (a system that required feudal lords to reside in Edo every other year) facilitated the active transmission of culture between Edo and the provinces.

sen.j: 一方で、膨大な人口が農村から江戸に流入して、様々な都市問題を引き起こすことにもなった。
sen.e: On the other hand, however, the mass-migration of people from farming villages to Edo caused various urban problems.
On the other hand, a massive influx of migrants from rural farming villages to Edo caused various urban problems.
On the other hand, a massive influx of migrants from rural farming villages to Edo caused various urban problems.

tit.e: Population and literacy rate of Edo
Population and literacy rate in Edo
Population and literacy rate in Edo

sen.j: ロドリゴ・デ・ビベロによって1609年ごろに15万人と伝えられた江戸の人口は、18世紀初頭には100万人を超え、世界一ないしはそれに匹敵する規模であったと推定されている。
sen.e: It is estimated that after Rodrigo de Vivero reported Edo's population as 150,000 around 1609, it exceeded one million at the beginning of the 18th century and Edo became the biggest or an equivalent-sized city in the world.

The population of Edo, which was reported by Rodrigo de Viveroto be around one-hundred-fifty-thousand in 1609, exceeded the one million mark at the turn of the eighteenth century--prompting many to presume that Edo had become one of the biggest if not the biggest city in the world.
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; population offered in arabic numerals retranslated in English to ensure consistency.
sen.e: The population of Edo, which was reported by Rodrigo de Viveroto be around one-hundred-fifty-thousand in 1609, exceeded the one million mark at the turn of the eighteenth century--prompting many to presume that Edo had become one of the biggest if not the biggest city in the world.

sen.j: 成人男性の識字率も幕末には70%を超え、同時期のロンドン（20%）、パリ（10%未満）を遥かに凌ぎ、ロシア人革命家メーチニコフや、トロイア遺跡を発見したドイツ人のハインリッヒ・シュリーマンらが、驚きを以って書いている。
sen.e: The literacy rate of adult males living in Edo exceeded 70 per cent at the end of Edo Period, by far higher than those of London (20%) and Paris (below 10%), which a Russian revolutionist, Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov, and a German archaeologist, Heinrich Julius Schliemann who discovered Trojan Ruins, reported with astonishment.

The literacy rate of adult males living in Edo exceeded seventy per cent by the end of Edo Period, far higher than those of London (20%) and Paris (below 10%), which a Russian revolutionist, Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov, and German archaeologist, Heinrich Julius Schliemann who discovered Trojan Ruins, reported with astonishment.
sen.cmt: Comparing the literacy rates between Edo and contemporary European cities is fine, but I don't see the relevance of the rest.
sen.e: The literacy rate of adult males living in Edo exceeded seventy per cent by the end of Edo Period, far higher than those of London (20%) and Paris (below 10%), which a Russian revolutionist, Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov, and German archaeologist, Heinrich Julius Schliemann who discovered Trojan Ruins, reported with astonishment.

sen.j: また、武家だけではなく農民も和歌を嗜んだと言われており、その背景には寺子屋の普及があったと考えられている。
sen.e: It is also said that not only samurai but also peasants could write waka (Japanese poetry), and it is considered that popularized terakoya private schools greatly contributed to the high literacy rate of Edo.

It is also said that waka (Japanese poetry) was not only cherished by samura, but also peasants- it is considered that this is a result of the popularization of terakoya (elementary education offered in temples).
sen.cmt: Initial translation significantly differs from the original--and includes additional information of the first translator; 嗜んだ=cherished; I object to the characterization of "terakoya" as "private schools" since many were established for the purpose of making education available to those children whose families could not have otherwise afforded education.
sen.e: It is also said that waka (Japanese poetry) was not only cherished by samura, but also peasants- it is considered that this is a result of the popularization of terakoya (elementary education offered in temples).

sen.j: その様に世界的に見れば極めて高い水準であると言うことができる。
sen.e: It is safe to say that compared to other parts of the world, Edo's literacy rate was very high.
In this manner, one can say that the literacy rate in Edo was significantly high vis-à-vis the rest of the world.
sen.cmt: The term 極めて is mistranslated as "kime," when it should be "kiwamete"-- a word that denoting the extremity of adjectives that follows it.
sen.e: In this manner, one can say that the literacy rate in Edo was significantly high vis-à-vis the rest of the world.

sen.j: ただ、人口に関しては、記録に残っているのは幕末に60万人近くとなった町人人口のみである。
sen.e: As for population, extant records only tell the number of townspeople; it was around 0.6 million at the end of the Edo Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, as for population, extant records only reveal the number of townspeople, which was close to six-hundred thousand in the waning days of the Bakufu.
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; numerals speleed out in English.
sen.e: However, as for population, extant records only reveal the number of townspeople, which was close to six-hundred thousand in the waning days of the Bakufu.

sen.j: 人口100万人とは、幕府による調査が行われていない武家や神官・僧侶などの寺社方、被差別階級などの統計で除外された人口を加えた推計値である。
sen.e: "One million people" is no more than a total estimated figure which included demographics not targeted in the population census, such as samurai households, Jisha-gata (those working for shrines and temples including Shinto priests and Buddhist monks), and discriminated classes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "One million people" is an approximate figure based on the retroactive inclusion of several elements of society such as the samurai households, Jisha-gata (those working for shrines and temples including Shinto priests and Buddhist monks), and ostracized castes who were not included in the original population census.
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; I think the term "discriminated class" is in correct, although the translation itself is correct, I think ostracized caste is more appropriate.
sen.e: "One million people" is an approximate figure based on the retroactive inclusion of several elements of society such as the samurai households, Jisha-gata (those working for shrines and temples including Shinto priests and Buddhist monks), and ostracized castes who were not included in the original population census.

sen.j: 武士の人口は、参勤交代に伴う地方からの単身赴任者など、流動的な部分が非常に多く、その推定は20万人程度から100万人程度までとかなりの幅があり、最盛期の江戸の総人口も68万人から150万人まで様々な推定値が出されている。
sen.e: Also, the estimated population of the samurai class ranges from 0.2 million to 1 million as it was very fluid due to the Sankinkotai system, which ordered provincial samurai to live in Edo every other year, and the total estimated population at the peak of the Edo Period also varies, ranging between 0.68 million and 1.5 million.

Estimates for the samurai residing in Edo vastly ranges between two-hundred thousand and one million due to many fluctuating factors such as the unaccompanied assignments of regional samura in accordance to the requirements of the Sankinkotai system, and the total population for Edo during its apex has ranged from 680,000 to 1.5 million.

Estimates for the samurai residing in Edo vastly ranges between two-hundred thousand and one million due to many fluctuating factors such as the unaccompanied assignments of regional samura in accordance to the requirements of the Sankinkotai system, and the total population for Edo during its apex has ranged from 680,000 to 1.5 million.

sen.j: 雑記等に記される同時代人の推定も50万人から200万人まで幅がある。
sen.e: According to 'Miscellaneous notes', the total estimated population of the same period also ranges from 0.5 million to 2 million.
Estimates of the population offered by miscellaneous documents of contemporaries also vary widely between five-hundred-thousand and two million.
sen.cmt: According to 'Miscellaneous notes', the total estimated population of the same period also ranges from 0.5 million to 2 million.
sen.e: Estimates of the population offered by miscellaneous documents of contemporaries also vary widely between five-hundred-thousand and two million.

sen.j: 町奉行支配下の町方・寺社方町人人口
sen.e: Population of townspeople (Machi-gata and Jishsa-gata) living in the area ruled by machi-bugyo (the town magistrate's office)
Population of townspeople and clerical personnel (Machi-gata and Jisha-gata) residing in areas administered by the machi-bugyo (the town magistrate's office).
sen.cmt: Spelling errors; elision in translation; stylistic changes.
sen.e: Population of townspeople and clerical personnel (Machi-gata and Jisha-gata) residing in areas administered by the machi-bugyo (the town magistrate's office).

sen.j: 江戸の国勢調査の最古の記録は、『正宝事録』の註釈として記された元禄六年（1693年）六月十七日の35万3588人であり、徳川綱吉が浮説雑説を唱えた者を探すために行われたものである。
sen.e: According to the annotation of "Shoho Jiroku", the oldest record of a census of Edo, the population of Edo on June 17, 1693 was 353,588, and the census was conducted by Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA to crack down on people who spoke of rumors and tales about the government.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The earliest extant record of a census conducted in Edo surivives in an annotation in the "Shoho Jiroku," (Chronicles of the Shoho Era) which indicates that there were 353,588 people in Edo as of June 17th, 1693 (6th year of Genroku), and it is also said that this was ordered by TOKUGAWA Tsunayoshi to root out demagogues.
sen.cmt: According to the annotation of "Shoho Jiroku," the oldest record of a census of Edo in June 17th, 1693 indicated that the population was 353,588, and that the census was conducted by TOKUGAWA Tsunayoshi to crack down on people who rumoured or spoke ill of the government.
sen.e: The earliest extant record of a census conducted in Edo surivives in an annotation in the "Shoho Jiroku," (Chronicles of the Shoho Era) which indicates that there were 353,588 people in Edo as of June 17th, 1693 (6th year of Genroku), and it is also said that this was ordered by Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA to root out demagogues.
sen.cmt: TOKUGAWA TsunayoshiをTsunayoshi TOKUGAWAに修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、実際に人口調査の体裁が整えられてたのは、徳川吉宗によって子午改（6年毎）の全国人口調査が開始された享保六年（1721年）以降であり、大岡忠相から有馬氏倫へ提出した書類の形式で伝えられている。
sen.e: However, the official format of a population census was established by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA in 1721 or later for a census to be conducted every six year, and the census records were presented in the form of documentation by Tadasuke OOKA to Ujinori ARIMA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the census system was only formally put into place after hexannual national census surveys were implemented by TOKUGAWA Yoshimune in 1721 (year) and formalized in the document presented by Ooka Tadasuke to ARIMA ARIMA.
sen.cmt: Stylistic issues; change in name order.
sen.e: However, the census system was only formally put into place after hexannual national census surveys were implemented by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA in 1721 (year) and formalized in the document presented by Tadasuke OOKA to Ujinori ARIMA.
sen.cmt: TOKUGAWA YoshimuneをYoshimune TOKUGAWAに修正しました。ARIMA ARIMAをUjinori ARIMAに修正しました。Ooka TadasukeをTadasuke OOKAに修正しました。

sen.j: 徳川吉宗は享保八年（1723年）九月から享保九年（1724年）四月の間の9263人の急激な人口減少、享保十年（1725年）四月から六月の間の1万0394人の急激な人口増加に気付き、季節的な人口変動の理由を調べさせた結果、冬の火災の多さから特に子女は近隣実家等へ疎開する、春以降火災からの復興再建や土蔵の建築が増えて労働転入者も増える、などといった実態が判明している。
sen.e: As gathering the information on population, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA noticed a sharp decline by 9,263 from September of 1723 to April of 1724 and also a surge by 10,394 from April of 1725 to June, the same year, and ordered to investigate the cause of this rapid seasonal population change, and found out that frequent fires in winter drove women and children evacuated to neighboring towns or their birthplace and reconstruction works after fires and increased building works of dozo (earthen storehouse) after spring brought in workers.

In gathering demographic information, TOKUGAWA Yoshimune noticed a sharp population decline of 9,263 persons between September 1723 to April 1724 and a population surge of 10,394 persons between April and June 1725; After ordering an investigation into the seasonal fluctuations in population, it was discovered that frequent fires in winter prompted women and children to take shelter in neighboring towns and parental residences, and reconstruction work and the construction of dozo (earthen storehouse) from spring brought in an influx of workers.

In gathering demographic information, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA noticed a sharp population decline of 9,263 persons between September 1723 to April 1724 and a population surge of 10,394 persons between April and June 1725; After ordering an investigation into the seasonal fluctuations in population, it was discovered that frequent fires in winter prompted women and children to take shelter in neighboring towns and parental residences, and reconstruction work and the construction of dozo (earthen storehouse) from spring brought in an influx of workers.
sen.cmt: TOKUGAWA YoshimuneをYoshimune TOKUGAWAに修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸の範囲は随時変わっており、寺社門前地が正式に御所内に組み込まれたのは1745年以降であり、朱引・墨引という呼称ができたのは1818年以降である。
sen.e: The official border of Edo changed frequently and it was not until 1745 or later that Jisha-Monzenchi (lands in front of gates of temples and shrines) were officially incorporated into the Imperial Palace, and also not until 1818 or later that the words of 'Shubiki' (drawing a border of Edo-fu in red) and 'Sumibiki' (drawing a border of the area ruled by the town magistrate's office in black) were coined.

The official borders of Edo changed frequently, and it was not until after 1745 that Jisha-Monzenchi (lands in fron to of temples and shrines) were officially incorporated into the Imperial Palace, and it was also not until 1818 that the terms 'Shubiki' (drawing a border of Edo-fu in red) and 'Sumibiki' (drawing a border of the area ruled by the town magistrate's office in black) were coined.

The official borders of Edo changed frequently, and it was not until after 1745 that Jisha-Monzenchi (lands in fron to of temples and shrines) were officially incorporated into the Imperial Palace, and it was also not until 1818 that the terms 'Shubiki' (drawing a border of Edo-fu in red) and 'Sumibiki' (drawing a border of the area ruled by the town magistrate's office in black) were coined.

sen.j: 明治二年(1869年)四月に施行された江戸市街調査によると江戸は町地269万6千坪(8.91 km2, 15.8%)、寺社地266万1千坪 (8.80 km2, 15.6%)、武家地1169万2千坪(38.65 km2, 68.6%)より構成されていたが、この内武家地の人口は江戸時代を通じて調査より除外された。
sen.e: According to the urban survey conducted in April 1869, Edo was comprised of 15.8% of lands for ordinary town use (8.91 km2), 15.6% of those for temples and shrines (8.80 km2) and 68.6% of those for samurai households (38.65 km2), but populations living in the lands for samurai households were never surveyed throughout the Edo Period.

A municipal survey conducted in April 1869, revealed that land usage in Edo comprised 15.8% of lands for ordinary town use (8.91 km2), 15.6% of those for temples and shrines (8.80 km2) and 68.6% of those for samurai households (38.65 km2), but populations living in the lands for samurai households were not included in the census throughout the Edo Period.

A municipal survey conducted in April 1869, revealed that land usage in Edo comprised 15.8% of lands for ordinary town use (8.91 km2), 15.6% of those for temples and shrines (8.80 km2) and 68.6% of those for samurai households (38.65 km2), but populations living in the lands for samurai households were not included in the census throughout the Edo Period.

sen.j: 出典のうち『江戸会雑誌』や勝海舟の『吹塵録』、『江戸旧事考』、『統計学雑誌』などは明治時代中ごろにまとめられた二次的史料であり、元となる江戸時代の史料が現在では不明となっている。
sen.e: Sources such as "Edo-kai zasshi", "Suijinroku" of Kaishu KATSU, "Edo Kyujiko" and "Tokeigaku zasshi" were secondary historical materials, as they were compiled in the middle of the Meiji Period, and the historical sources written in the Edo Period on which these documents were based are unaccounted for at present.

Sources such as "Edo-kai zasshi", "Suijinroku" of Kaishu KATSU, "Edo Kyujiko" and "Tokeigaku zasshi" are secondary materials materials compiled in the mid-Meiji Period, and the primary documents on which these secondary sources are are based have not been accounted for.

Sources such as "Edo-kai zasshi", "Suijinroku" of Kaishu KATSU, "Edo Kyujiko" and "Tokeigaku zasshi" are secondary materials materials compiled in the mid-Meiji Period, and the primary documents on which these secondary sources are are based have not been accounted for.

sen.j: 斜体で示した数字は (1) 他の年月に酷似した数字が登場しており、共に誤記が疑われるケース (2) 元の史料の人口に対して寺社方人口や新吉原などの計外人口を独自に加算したと推測されるケースのいずれかであり、信頼性が低い。
sen.e: The figures in italic face are not reliable either because 1. writing errors are suspected as similar numbers frequently appear over different months, or 2. it is highly likely that populations of Shaji-kata and those living in Shin-yoshiwara are added to official figures in later times.

The figures in italics are of questionable accuracy because (1) the recurrence of similar figures over several months points to the likelihood of entry errors; and (2) there are several cases in which the populations of Shaji-kata and Shin-yoshiwara that were not included in the original estimates were retroactively added to the figures in later times.

The figures in italics are of questionable accuracy because (1) the recurrence of similar figures over several months points to the likelihood of entry errors; and (2) there are several cases in which the populations of Shaji-kata and Shin-yoshiwara that were not included in the original estimates were retroactively added to the figures in later times.

sen.j: 公文書で出稼人を加えた町人人口が最大（58万7458人）となったのは天保十四年七月（1843年）であり、出稼人を除いた町人人口が最大（57万5901人）となったのは嘉永六年九月（1853年）のことである。
sen.e: According to official documents, it was July 1843 that the population of townspeople including migrant workers reached the largest (587,458) and also in September 1853 that the population excluding migrant workers did the same (575,901).

Official documents reveal that the total migrant population combined with the population of townspeople reached its apex (587,458) in July 1843 (Kyoho 14), and the population of townspeople excluding migrant workers reached its apex (575,901) in September 1853 (Kaei 6).

sen.j: 但し『江戸旧事考』は出稼人を加えた町人人口が最大となった天保十四年の人口を59万6448人とし（内訳等の数字は公文書の天保十四年七月のものと似ている）、出稼人を除いた町人人口が最大になった数字として100年前の寛保二年（1742年）の59万1809人を挙げている（『江戸旧事考』の数字は多くの場合計外人口を加算しているものと思われる）。
sen.e: However, according to "Edo Kyujiko", the population of 1843, when Edo was the most populous including migrant workers, was 596,448, (its broken-down figures are similar to those in the official document of July 1843), and the biggest population excluding migrant workers was 591,809 as of 1742, a hundred years before the official record (however, most figures in "Edo Kyujiko" are believed to cover non-targeted demographics as well).

However, according to the "Edo Kyujiko" (Ruminations on Old Edo) Edo's population reached its height in 1843 with approximately 596,448 including migrant workers (The broken-down figures are similar to those in the official document of July 1843.); excluding migrant workers, the Edo population reached its height in 1742--a hundred years before the official census (Most of the figures in the "Edo Kyujiko" are believed to cover non-targeted demographic subjects as well.") with a local population of 591,809 as of 1742, a hundred years before the official record (however, most figures in "Edo Kyujiko" are believed to cover non-targeted demographics as well).

sen.e: Also, according to "Edokai zasshi", the population of 1803 was 607,100 (however, it seems the male population overstated by 100,000).
Also, according to "Edokai zasshi,"the population in New Years 1803 (Japanese Years) was 607,100 (However, it is believed that the male population was mistakenly overstated by 100,000).
Also, according to "Edokai zasshi,"the population in New Years 1803 (Japanese Years) was 607,100 (However, it is believed that the male population was mistakenly overstated by 100,000).

sen.j: 江戸は地方からの上京者が多く、江戸時代中期には男性が女性の倍近くいたが、末期には男女差がかなり解消された。
sen.e: Edo had many migrants from provinces, and in the middle of the Edo Period, male population was double the number of female one, but the population difference was significantly reduced by the end of the Period.

Many provincial migrants, many of whom were male, resided in Edo to the extent that the male population was nearly double that of the female population in the mid-Edo period, this gender imbalance was greatly alleviated by the end of period.
sen.cmt: Stylistic Changes; unnecessary capitals; The original Japanese text can be clearer (It should state that the majority of migrants were male, which is obvious, but only implied in the text).
sen.e: Many provincial migrants, many of whom were male, resided in Edo to the extent that the male population was nearly double that of the female population in the mid-Edo period, this gender imbalance was greatly alleviated by the end of period.

sen.j: このほか大田南畝の『半日閑話』、岩瀬京山の『蜘蛛の糸』、『乙巳雑記上』などは、天明六年十月廿八日（1786年）または天明七年五月廿五日以降（1787年）に江戸の町人の人口が100万人を超える128万5300人であったと伝えている。
sen.e: Other sources including "Hannichi Kanwa" of Nanbo OTA and "Kumo no Ito" and "乙巳雑記上" of Kyozan IWASE, describe that in 1786 or 1787, the population of townspeople reached over one million, 1,285,300. to be exact.
sen.cmt: 乙巳雑記上：読み方不明です。
sen.e: Other sources including OTA Nanbo's "Hannichi Kanwa" and "Kumo no Ito" and IWASE Kyozan's "Otomizakki jo" point that the population of towns people exceeded the one million mark and reached 1,285,300 by June 1786 (Tenmei 6) or May 1787 (Tenmei), t.

Other sources including Nanbo OTA's "Hannichi Kanwa" and "Kumo no Ito" and Kyozan IWASE's "Otomizakki jo" point that the population of towns people exceeded the one million mark and reached 1,285,300 by June 1786 (Tenmei 6) or May 1787 (Tenmei), t.
sen.cmt: 個人名、姓名の順に修正しました。

sen.j: また天保八年（1837年）の人口として128万4815人という数字も伝わっている。
sen.e: Also, another source describes the figure for 1837 was 1,284,815.
Another source indicates that the population in 1837 (Tenpo 8) was 1,284,815.
Another source indicates that the population in 1837 (Tenpo 8) was 1,284,815.

sen.j: 共に災害の直後の非常時であったため、これらが武家人口を含めた真の江戸の人口であるとする解釈があるが、(1) 男女比が逆転している (2) 50年隔てた両年の人口や後述の計外人口の構成が酷似しているなど信頼性が低い。
sen.e: Some people believe that these numbers include samurai households, and therefore they reflect a true size of the town, because the statistics were carried out in the time of emergency immediately after disasters, but it is unreliable because 1. the male-to-female ratio was switched, and 2. the populations of targeted demographics, as well as the ones of non-targeted demographics are very close in the two different years over 50 years of interval.

Some have interpreted that these figures, collected shortly after a state of emergency due to a disaster, reveal the true population of Edo that takes into account the population of samurai households, but the reliability of this document is questionable because (1) the male-to-female ratio is reversed, and (2) the populations and composition of non-targeted demographics are similar in spite of a fifty year interval.
sen.cmt: I find it really strange that the original Japanese document does not include any information concerning "災害の直後の非常時," If it is so significant, such information should not be elided; Stylistic changes.
sen.e: Some have interpreted that these figures, collected shortly after a state of emergency due to a disaster, reveal the true population of Edo that takes into account the population of samurai households, but the reliability of this document is questionable because (1) the male-to-female ratio is reversed, and (2) the populations and composition of non-targeted demographics are similar in spite of a fifty year interval.

sen.j: 新吉原、神官・僧侶の人口
sen.e: Population of Shin-yoshiwara (a red light district), Shinto priest and Buddhist monk
Population of the Shin-yoshiwara (The red light district), Shinto Priests and Buddhist Monks
sen.cmt: Capitals; Pluralized; (Assuming that this is a title).
sen.e: Population of the Shin-yoshiwara (The red light district), Shinto Priests and Buddhist Monks

sen.j: 吉原 (東京都)は1657年の明暦の大火の際に江戸郊外に作られた居住地区であったが、安政元年よりも前は町奉行の支配下に入っておらず、江戸御府内人口の統計から除外されてきた。
sen.e: As Yoshiwara (Tokyo Prefecture), a residential area built in the suburb of Edo after the Great Fire of Meireki of 1657, was outside the control of the town magistrate's office, it was excluded from population statistics of Edo-fu Prefecture.

Although the Yoshiwara (Tokyo Prefecture) was initially constructed as a residential in a suburb of Edo after the Great Fire of Meireki in 1657, it remained outside the control of the town magistrate's office and was excluded from the census taken within Edo Prefecture.

Although the Yoshiwara (Tokyo Prefecture) was initially constructed as a residential in a suburb of Edo after the Great Fire of Meireki in 1657, it remained outside the control of the town magistrate's office and was excluded from the census taken within Edo Prefecture.

sen.j: また神官・僧侶は特殊階級とみなされ、人口の統計から除外されている。
sen.e: Also, Shint priests and Buddhist monks were regarded as a special class and therefore, they were also excluded from a population census.
Additionally, Shinto priests and Buddhist monks were regarded as belonging to a special class and excluded from a population census.
Additionally, Shinto priests and Buddhist monks were regarded as belonging to a special class and excluded from a population census.

sen.j: 以下複数の雑記に記録されている計外人口を列挙する。
sen.e: The following is the list of population figures not covered by a census but recorded in a several miscellaneous notes.

sen.j: しかし、時代を超えて数字が酷似していることから、数点の元史料をもとに数字が伝えられ、誤記により変化した考えられる。
sen.e: However, as the figures are quite similar throughout the ages, it is believed that they were based on one or two sources and mis-descripted.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, since the figures remain oddly similar over time, it is thought that they were plagiarized from several historical documents, but changed over time through mis-transcription.
However, since the figures remain oddly similar over time, it is thought that they were plagiarized from several historical documents, but changed over time through mis-transcription.

sen.j: 寺社方人口として一番控えめな数字を採用すると約4万人程度となる。
sen.e: The most modest population figure of Jisha-gata is around 40,000.
The most conservative estimates for temple and shrine constituents point to a population of 40,000.
The most conservative estimates for temple and shrine constituents point to a population of 40,000.

sen.j: また新吉原の人口は約1万人程度である。

sen.j: 御府内の範囲は時代によって異なり、特に寺社門前町の取り扱いについては幕府役人の間でも問い合わせがあった。
sen.e: The area governed by the town magistrate's office frequently changed over times, and especially how to handle temple towns was a big challenge for magistrate officers.
The area governed by the town magistrate's office varied with time, and the handling of temple/shrine towns was a particularly troublesome issue among Bakufu officials.
The area governed by the town magistrate's office varied with time, and the handling of temple/shrine towns was a particularly troublesome issue among Bakufu officials.

sen.j: 実際朱印内であってもかなりの農地が武家屋敷とともに存在した。
sen.e: Indeed, even in Shuinchi (lands allocated for temples and shrines), a fair amount of farm lands existed along with samurai residences.
Indeed, a significant number of farm plots and samurai residences existed in Shuinchi (lands allocated for temples and shrines).
Indeed, a significant number of farm plots and samurai residences existed in Shuinchi (lands allocated for temples and shrines).

sen.j: そのため町奉行支配下の町人人口として計上されている寺社門前地の人口には、農地に点在する農民、一部町人の人口が含まれていないとする解釈がある。
sen.e: Therefore, some say that populations of temple towns, which were incorporated into the population of townspeople, do not include peasants living in such farm lands and some other townspeople living in the Shuinchi.

For the abovementioned reason, there are those who interpret that the population of temple towns that have been accounted for in the population of townspeople, do not include peasants living in such farm lands and some other townspeople inhabiting the shuinchi.
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; diction; unnecessary capitals removed.
sen.e: For the abovementioned reason, there are those who interpret that the population of temple towns that have been accounted for in the population of townspeople, do not include peasants living in such farm lands and some other townspeople inhabiting the shuinchi.

sen.j: 鷹見安二郎（1940年）によると住宅密集地区外に点在する民家は文政年間で約9500戸程度と見積もられ、約4万3500人程度である。
sen.e: Yasujiro TAKAMI (1940) estimated that in the Bunsei era, there were around 9,500 households outside of the ordinary residential area, about 43,500 people in total.
TAKAMI Yasujiro (1940) estimated that there were 9,500 households and approximately 43,500 people inhabiting the dense residential area.
