sen.j: 武家屋敷に使用人として住む町人の人口は、幕府の管理下になかったため、江戸の人口統計から除外されている。
sen.e: The population of servants living in samurai residences was not under control of bakufu, and therefore, it was excluded from population statistics of Edo.
The population of servants living in samurai residences was excluded from the Edo census because it was not an administrative responsibility of the Bakufu.
sen.cmt: Good translation of the original Japanese document, but I think it was also quite literal. Considering the context, a change in style was necessary.
sen.e: The population of servants living in samurai residences was excluded from the Edo census because it was not an administrative responsibility of the Bakufu.

sen.j: また軍事機密保持なども理由に、武士階級全体の人口がそもそも統計として残っていない。
sen.e: Also, in order to maintain confidentiality on military matters, populations of samurai were never counted throughout the Period.
Furthermore, the population of the samurai was never recorded since it was strategically sensitive information.
sen.cmt: Again, it could have been literally translated as "Furthermore, the population of samura was never recorded for the reason of protecting military secrets- among other reasons," but I have chosen to avoid such a translation in favor of a more streamlined version.
sen.e: Furthermore, the population of the samurai was never recorded since it was strategically sensitive information.

sen.j: いくつかの雑記は江戸在中の武士の人口として2億人を超える荒唐無稽な数値（享保十七年四月（1732年） 2億3698万7950人（『月堂見聞集』）、享保二十年（1735年）：2億3608万5950人（『半日閑話』）、寛政三年（1743年）及び文化十二年（1815年）：2億3658万0390人（『甲子夜話』））を記載しているが、唯一『土屋筆記』は御屋敷方の人口として70万0973人（年次不明）という比較的現実的な人口を伝えている。
sen.e: In a several miscellaneous notes, populations of samurai residing in Edo were irrationally estimated as large as over 0.2 billion (236,987,950 in 1732 ["Getudo Kenmon shu"], 236,085,950 in 1735 ["Hannichi Kanwa"] and 236,580,390 in 1743 and 1815 ["Kasshi yawa"]), whereas "Tsuchiya Hikki" describes a realistic figure of 600,973 (years unknown).

In a several miscellaneous notes, populations of samurai residing in Edo were irrationally estimated as large as over 0.2 billion (236,987,950 in 1732 ["Getudo Kenmon shu"], 236,085,950 in 1735 ["Hannichi Kanwa"] and 236,580,390 in 1743 and 1815 ["Kasshi yawa"]), whereas "Tsuchiya Hikki" describes a realistic figure of 600,973 (years unknown).

In a several miscellaneous notes, populations of samurai residing in Edo were irrationally estimated as large as over 0.2 billion (236,987,950 in 1732 ["Getudo Kenmon shu"], 236,085,950 in 1735 ["Hannichi Kanwa"] and 236,580,390 in 1743 and 1815 ["Kasshi yawa"]), whereas "Tsuchiya Hikki" describes a realistic figure of 600,973 (years unknown).

sen.j: また『柳烟雑記』は享保九年五月（1723年）の武家人口として、大名264人、旗本5205人、御目見以下1万7004人、与力・同心並びに六尺・下男3万0909人、その他487人と伝えている。
sen.e: Also, according to "柳烟雑記," samurai warriors in 1723 was comprised of 242 daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), 5,205 hatamoto (bannermen), 17,004 of those below these ranks, 30,909 yoriki (police sergeant), doshin (police constable), rokushaku (servant), genan (houseboy), and 487 others.
sen.cmt: 柳烟雑記：読み方不明です。
sen.e: Additionally, according to the "Ryuenzakki" [柳烟雑記] (Miscellaneous Records of Smokey Willow), the samurai population as of May 1723 (Kyoho 9) comprised of 264 daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), 5,205 hatamoto (bannermen), 17,004 subordinates, 30,909 of those including yoriki (police sergeant), doshin (police constable), rokushaku (servant) and genan (houseboy), and 487 others.
sen.cmt: The population of Daimyo has been mistranscribed; dates elided in the original
sen.e: Additionally, according to the "Ryuenzakki" [柳烟雑記] (Miscellaneous Records of Smokey Willow), the samurai population as of May 1723 (Kyoho 9) comprised of 264 daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), 5,205 hatamoto (bannermen), 17,004 subordinates, 30,909 of those including yoriki (police sergeant), doshin (police constable), rokushaku (servant) and genan (houseboy), and 487 others.

sen.j: 小宮山綏介（1891年）は、『柳烟雑記』の統計を元に諸藩の在府者と家族の人口を12万1100人、旗本御家人と家族の人口を8万3403人、その家来・従事者5万8936人、合計約26万人程度と推定している。
sen.e: Yasusuke KOMIYAMA (1891) estimated based on the statistics from "柳烟雑記" that the total population of samurai households was around 260,000; 121,110 of domain-retained samurai and their family, 83,403 of hatamoto and their family, and 58,936 of their retainers and servants.
sen.cmt: 柳烟雑記：読み方不明です。
sen.e: Yasusuke KOMIYAMA (1891) estimated based on the statistics from "柳烟雑記" that the total population of samurai households was around 260,000; 121,110 of domain-retained samurai and their family, 83,403 of hatamoto and their family, and 58,936 of their retainers and servants.

Yasusuke KOMIYAMA (1891) estimated based on the statistics from "柳烟雑記" that the total population of samurai households was around 260,000; 121,110 of domain-retained samurai and their family, 83,403 of hatamoto and their family, and 58,936 of their retainers and servants.

sen.j: また天保十四年の調査に対しては、合計約30万人程度と推定している。
sen.e: Also, his total estimate of samurai households for 1843 is around 300,000.
Additionally, a survey performed in 1843 (Tenpo 14) estimates the total population to be approximately 300,000.
Additionally, a survey performed in 1843 (Tenpo 14) estimates the total population to be approximately 300,000.

sen.j: 一方鷹見安二郎（1940年）は明治初年の華族・士族人口や石高の統計などをもとに、諸藩の在府者と家族の人口を約36万人、幕府配下の武家と家族の人口を約26万人、合計約62万人と推定している。
sen.e: On the other hand, Yasujiro TAKAMI (1940) estimated, based on the population statistics conducted in 1868 on peerage and warrior classes and crop yields, that the total population of samurai households was around 620,000, with 360,000 of domain-retained samurai and their family and 260,000 of bakufu-retained samurai and their family.

On the other hand, Yasujiro TAKAMI (1940) estimated the population of domain-retained samura and their dependents to be approximately 360,000, and the population of samurai and dependents administered by the Bakufu to be approximately 260,000 for a combined total of 620,000 based on an 1864 (meiji 1) census carried out over peerage and warrior classes.

On the other hand, Yasujiro TAKAMI (1940) estimated the population of domain-retained samura and their dependents to be approximately 360,000, and the population of samurai and dependents administered by the Bakufu to be approximately 260,000 for a combined total of 620,000 based on an 1864 (meiji 1) census carried out over peerage and warrior classes.

sen.j: 関山直太郎（1958年）は、旗本御家人と家族約11万5千人、その家来・従属者約10万人、諸藩の在府者と家族約18万人、幕府直属の足軽・奉公人等約10万人、合計約50万人と推定している。
sen.e: While SEKYAMA Naotaro (1958) estimated that the total population of samurai households was around 500,000, including 115,000 of hatamoto and their family, 100,000 of their servants, 180,000 of domain-retained samurai and their family, and 100,000 of ashigaru (common foot soldier) retained by bakufu and their servants.

On the other hand, Naotaro SEKIYAMA (1958) estimated that the aggregate population of samurai households was around 500,000, composed of 115,000 hatamoto and their dependents, 100,000 of their servants, 180,000 domain-retained samurai and their dependents, and 100,000 of ashigaru (common foot soldier) and servants retained by Bakufu.
sen.cmt: Name Order; Stylistic changes; Mistranslation (How can ashigaru (common foot soldiers) have their own servants?)
sen.e: On the other hand, Naotaro SEKIYAMA (1958) estimated that the aggregate population of samurai households was around 500,000, composed of 115,000 hatamoto and their dependents, 100,000 of their servants, 180,000 domain-retained samurai and their dependents, and 100,000 of ashigaru (common foot soldier) and servants retained by Bakufu.

sen.j: 過去の人口推定値として海外でしばしば引用されるTertius Chandler（1987年）は、町奉行支配下の町人人口の3/8程度を武士人口とし、18万8千人（1701年）から約21万5千人（1854年）と見積もっている。
sen.e: Tertius Chandler, whose population estimates are frequently cited in other countries, estimated that three-eighth of the population of townspeople was samurai, ranging from 188,000 (1701) to 215,000 (1854).

Tertius Chandler, whose estimates for historical populations are frequently cited in other countries, estimated that three-eighths of the population of townspeople were samurai, and approximated the demographic shift from 188,000 in 1701 to 215,000 1854.

Tertius Chandler, whose estimates for historical populations are frequently cited in other countries, estimated that three-eighths of the population of townspeople were samurai, and approximated the demographic shift from 188,000 in 1701 to 215,000 1854.

sen.j: 1868年に戊辰戦争が起こり、鳥羽・伏見の戦いで幕府軍が敗れると、薩摩藩長州藩軍の大軍が江戸に迫り、江戸は戦火に晒される危険に陥った。
sen.e: The Boshin War started in 1868 with the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, and when the bakufu army was defeated in the Battle, a large force of Satsuma and Choshu Domains advanced to Edo, putting Edo under the threat of warfare.

The Boshin War broke out in 1868, and when the Bakufu army was defeated in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, a large force of combined Satsuma and Choshu Domains advanced on Edo, putting the metropolis under the threat of warfare.
sen.cmt: Diction; Mistranslation (The Battle of Toba Fushimi was not the first engagement of the Boshin War).
sen.e: The Boshin War broke out in 1868, and when the Bakufu army was defeated in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, a large force of combined Satsuma and Choshu Domains advanced on Edo, putting the metropolis under the threat of warfare.

sen.j: 幕臣勝海舟は早期停戦を唱えて薩長軍を率いる西郷隆盛と交渉、最後の将軍徳川慶喜は江戸城の無血開城し降伏、交戦派と官軍の間の上野戦争を例外として、江戸は戦火を免れた（江戸開城）。
sen.e: A shogun's retainer, Kaishu KATSU, advocated an early cease-fire and negotiated with Takamori SAIGO who lead the Saccho army, and as a result, the last shogun, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, surrendered the Edo Castle without shedding any blood, saving Edo from warfare, except the Battle of Ueno between domain fighters and the government army.
sen.cmt: 交戦派：意味不明瞭です。
sen.e: KATSU Kaishu, a retainer of the Shogun, advocated an early cease-fire with SAIGO Takamori --commander of combined Satsuma and Choshu forces; Consequently, the last Shogun TOKUGAWA Yoshinobu surrendered Edo Castle without any bloodshed and spared Edo from the ravages of war with the exception of the Battle of Ueno fought between domain and government forces.

Kaishu KATSU, a retainer of the Shogun, advocated an early cease-fire with Takamori SAIGO--commander of combined Satsuma and Choshu forces; Consequently, the last Shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA surrendered Edo Castle without any bloodshed and spared Edo from the ravages of war with the exception of the Battle of Ueno fought between domain and government forces.
sen.cmt: 個人名、姓名の順に修正しました。

sen.j: 同年、江戸は東京と改名され、翌1869年には東京城（江戸城）に東京行幸した明治天皇が入って「皇城」とされて、かつての将軍の居住する都市・江戸は、天皇の行在する都市・東京となった（東京奠都）。
sen.e: In the same year, Edo was renamed Tokyo and in the following 1869, the Tokyo Castle (formerly, the Edo Castle) was officially appointed as a temporal 'Imperial Palace' while Emperor Meiji was staying in the Castle, and the 'metropolis Edo' where shogun had once resided was turned into the 'metropolis Tokyo' where Emperor was staying temporarily (Tokyo Tento [transfer of the national capital to Tokyo]).

Shortly after the fall of the Bakufu, Edo renamed Tokyo, and in the following year the Tokyo Castle (formerly, the Edo Castle) was officially recommissioned as the 'Imperial Palace' with the 入居 of the Meiji Emperor-- the metropolis Edo once overseen by the shogun became the 'metropolis Tokyo'-- temporary residence of the Emperor (Tokyo Tento [transfer of the national capital to Tokyo]).
sen.cmt: I have translated this within the context of the rest of the document, eliding an unnecessary repetition of the year;
sen.e: Shortly after the fall of the Bakufu, Edo renamed Tokyo, and in the following year the Tokyo Castle (formerly, the Edo Castle) was officially recommissioned as the 'Imperial Palace' with the 入居 of the Meiji Emperor-- the metropolis Edo once overseen by the shogun became the 'metropolis Tokyo'-- temporary residence of the Emperor (Tokyo Tento [transfer of the national capital to Tokyo]).

sen.j: 東京の町並が東京市、東京都へと変遷しつつ拡大してゆく過程で、かつての江戸は都心となり、その中核としての役割を果たしている。
sen.e: As Tokyo was transforming itself into Tokyo City and to Tokyo Metropolis through territorial expansion, the area once-called Edo became a downtown area of Tokyo and is now playing a central role in Japan.
As the townscape of Tokyo expanded and transformed from a city to a metropolis, the area formerly known as Edo became downtown Tokyo, and serves as its center.
As the townscape of Tokyo expanded and transformed from a city to a metropolis, the area formerly known as Edo became downtown Tokyo, and serves as its center.

sen.j: 江戸の地名で呼ばれる地域は、元々は平安時代に存在した荏原郡桜田郷（江戸城の西南）の一部であったが、やがて豊島郡 (武蔵国)江戸郷と呼ばれるようになっていた。
sen.e: Originally, the area called Edo was a part of Sakurada-go, Ebara County (in the southwest of the Edo Castle) which existed in the Heian Period, but later named Edo-go, Toshima County (Musashi Province).

The area called Edo was originally part of the Heian Period village Sakurada-go in Ebara County (southwest of the Edo Castle), but it later became referred to as Edo-go of Toshima County (Musashi Province).

The area called Edo was originally part of the Heian Period village Sakurada-go in Ebara County (southwest of the Edo Castle), but it later became referred to as Edo-go of Toshima County (Musashi Province).

sen.j: 江戸時代前期頃の江戸の範囲は、現在の東京都千代田区とその周辺のみであり、江戸城の外堀はこれを取り囲むよう建造された。
sen.e: In the first half of the Edo Period, Edo was as small as current Chiyoda Ward and its surrounding areas, and the outer moat of the Edo Castle was constructed to surround the area.
In the first half of the Edo Period, the city was no bigger than present day Chiyoda Ward and its surrounding areas, and the outer moat of the Edo Castle was dug to encompass this area.
In the first half of the Edo Period, the city was no bigger than present day Chiyoda Ward and its surrounding areas, and the outer moat of the Edo Castle was dug to encompass this area.

sen.j: 明暦の大火以後、その市街地は拡大。
sen.e: After the Great Fire of Meireki, the urban area greatly expanded.
The urban areas expanded after the Great Fire of Meireki.
The urban areas expanded after the Great Fire of Meireki.

sen.j: 通称「八百八町」と呼ばれるようになる。
sen.e: Edo was grown to be called '808 towns'.
Edo came to be called as the city of "eight-hundred-and-eight towns' (The number eight-hundred-and-eight is traditionally associated with innumerable.).
sen.cmt: The cultural significance and meaning of the number 808 needs to be explained in parenthesis.
sen.e: Edo came to be called as the city of "eight-hundred-and-eight towns' (The number eight-hundred-and-eight is traditionally associated with innumerable.).

sen.j: 江戸の市域は「御府内」と呼ばれ、正式な区域は1818年に地図上の朱引きで、さらに町奉行の管轄する区域は墨引きで示されるようになった。
sen.e: The city area of Edo was called 'Gofunai' and the official border of Edo was indicated by 'Shubiki' (drawing a border of Edo-fu in red) for the first time in 1818 and the area ruled by the town magistrate's office was also indicated by 'Sumibiki' (drawing a border of the area ruled by the town magistrate's office) on a map.

The urban area of Edo was called 'Gofunai,' and the official borders of Edo cartographically delineated by 'shubiki' (literally "red-ruled lines.") for the first time in 1818, and the area administered by the town magistrate's office were distinguished by 'sumibiki' (literally "black-ruled lines").
sen.cmt: Diction; Stylistic changes; Japanese Dates added for consistency.
sen.e: The urban area of Edo was called 'Gofunai,' and the official borders of Edo cartographically delineated by 'shubiki' (literally "red-ruled lines.") for the first time in 1818, and the area administered by the town magistrate's office were distinguished by 'sumibiki' (literally "black-ruled lines").

sen.j: 朱引きは旧東京市の15区より若干広く、現在の豊島区、渋谷区、荒川区、北区 (東京都)、目黒区の一部、品川区の一部、板橋区の一部をも含む。
sen.e: The area indicated by 'Shubiki' was slightly larger than the fifteen Wards of the former Tokyo City, including the areas of current Toshima Ward, Shibuya Ward, Kita Ward and portions of Meguro, Shinagawa and Itabashi Wards.

The area encompassed by 'Shubiki' was slightly larger than the fifteen wards consisting Old Tokyo, and include parts of present day Toshima, Shibuya, and Kita wards, as well as parts of Meguro, Shinagawa, and Itabashi wards.

The area encompassed by 'Shubiki' was slightly larger than the fifteen wards consisting Old Tokyo, and include parts of present day Toshima, Shibuya, and Kita wards, as well as parts of Meguro, Shinagawa, and Itabashi wards.

sen.j: 墨引きは旧東京市の15区とほぼ一致する。
sen.e: The area indicated by 'Sumibiki' was almost equal in size to the fifteen Wards of the former Tokyo City.
The shubiki delineated areas roughly match with the fifteen wards of Old Tokyo.
The shubiki delineated areas roughly match with the fifteen wards of Old Tokyo.

sen.j: 朱引きは明治以降も存続し、数度の改正を経て、最終的には旧墨引に近い形となり郡区町村編制法施行時に旧東京15区となった。
sen.e: The practice of 'Shubiki' continued after the Meiji Period, and with a series of revisions, the area of Edo was officially set in accordance with the Act for the alignment of local government system to cover the fifteen Wards of the former Tokyo City, almost the same size as indicated by 'Sumibiki'.

The practice of 'shubiki' continued into the Meiji Period; After several revisions the shubiki areas assumed a shape similar to those of sumibiki areas, and the administrative boundaries of the fifteen wards of Old Tokyo were finalized in accordance to the promulgation of the County-Ward-Township-Village Organization Act.
sen.cmt: Stylistic changes; "郡区町村編制法" has been retranslated as County-Ward-Township-Village Organization Act.
sen.e: The practice of 'shubiki' continued into the Meiji Period; After several revisions the shubiki areas assumed a shape similar to those of sumibiki areas, and the administrative boundaries of the fifteen wards of Old Tokyo were finalized in accordance to the promulgation of the County-Ward-Township-Village Organization Act.

sen.j: 江戸は、江戸後期に現在の、千代田区・中央区 (東京都)・港区 (東京都)・新宿区の東側（四谷付近まで）・文京区・台東区・墨田区・江東区の辺り、のちの東京市の内十五区部分ぐらいまで広がったといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that in later Edo Period, Edo almost covered the fifteen Wards of later-Tokyo City, current Chiyoda Ward, Chuo Ward, Minato Ward, the east side of Shinjuku Ward (up to Yotsuya), Bunkyo Ward, Taito Ward, Sumida Ward and Koto Ward.

It is said that in later Edo Period, Edo almost encompassed fifteen Wards of later-Tokyo City, present-day Chiyoda, Chuo, Bunkyo, Taito, Sumida, and Koto wards, as well as the east side of Shinjuku Ward (up to Yotsuya).

It is said that in later Edo Period, Edo almost encompassed fifteen Wards of later-Tokyo City, present-day Chiyoda, Chuo, Bunkyo, Taito, Sumida, and Koto wards, as well as the east side of Shinjuku Ward (up to Yotsuya).

sen.j: 元々、徳川家康自身が岡崎市出身の一大名であったように、岡崎を初めとする西三河系の地名が、江戸には多く移植されている（例：秋葉原 三河の隣国、遠江国の秋葉山本宮秋葉神社に由来）。
sen.e: Because Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was originally a daimyo of Mikawa Province (present-day, Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture, Western Japan), Edo has a lot of place names from the west side of Mikawa, including Okazaki City (e.g. Akihabara is derived from Akihasan-hongu Akiha-jinja Shrine of Totomi Province, a neighboring province of Mikawa).

Many place names of Nishimikawa beginning with Ozaki, have been transposed to locations in Edo (For example, "Akihabara" was a name for a country bordering Mikawa, which originaltes from the Akihayama Motomiyaakiha Shring of the former country of Totoumi.), because TOKUGAWA Ieyasu was originally the daimyo of Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City of Aichi Prefecture in Western Japan.).

Many place names of Nishimikawa beginning with Ozaki, have been transposed to locations in Edo (For example, "Akihabara" was a name for a country bordering Mikawa, which originaltes from the Akihayama Motomiyaakiha Shrine of the former country of Totoumi.), because Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was originally the daimyo of Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City of Aichi Prefecture in Western Japan.).
sen.cmt: 個人名、姓名の順に修正しました。

sen.j: 実際には、既に触れたように江戸の地は平安時代末期から関東南部の要衝であった。
sen.e: In fact, as mentioned earlier, Edo had served as an important strategic place of the southern Kanto region since late Heian Period.
In fact, as mentioned earlier, the location of Edo was one of vital strategic importance in the southern Kanto region since the late Heian Period.
In fact, as mentioned earlier, the location of Edo was one of vital strategic importance in the southern Kanto region since the late Heian Period.

sen.j: 確かに徳川氏の記録が伝えるように、後北条氏時代の江戸城は最重要な支城とまではみなされず城は15世紀の粗末なつくりのまま残されていたが、関八州の首府となりうる基礎はすでに存在していた。
sen.e: It was true as records of the Tokugawa clan show that the Edo Castle in the era of the Gohojo clan was not regarded as the most important branch castle and left untouched and as humble as it was constructed in the 15th century, but Edo was certainly equipped with necessary features to be developed into a metropolis of the eight provinces of the Kanto region.

As the records of the Tokugawa clan reveal, the Edo Castle was not regarded as a vital branch-castle in the time of the Gohojo clan and its modest structure that was constructed in the 15th century remained; However, it should be noted that the foundations that would enable Edo to develop into the capital of eight provinces had already been laid.

As the records of the Tokugawa clan reveal, the Edo Castle was not regarded as a vital branch-castle in the time of the Gohojo clan and its modest structure that was constructed in the 15th century remained; However, it should be noted that the foundations that would enable Edo to develop into the capital of eight provinces had already been laid.

sen.j: しかし、江戸が都市として発展するためには、日比谷入江の東、隅田川河口の西にあたる江戸前島と呼ばれる砂州を除けば、城下町をつくるために十分な平地が存在しないことが大きな障害となる。
sen.e: However, it was a huge setback for Edo, in an effort to develop into a metropolis, to have scarce flatland to build a castle town, except Edo Maejima, a sandbar, located in the east of Hibiya cove and in the west of the estuary of Sumida-gawa River.

With the exception of the sandbar known as Edomaeshima, which is east of the Hibiya inlet and west of the Sumidagawa Estuary, the lack of level land not only posed a significant obstacle to development of the castletown, but also hampered the development of Edo into metropolis.
sen.cmt: Frankly, the phrase "と呼ばれる"doesn't translate very well into English- it is unnecessary.
sen.e: With the exception of the sandbar known as Edomaeshima, which is east of the Hibiya inlet and west of the Sumidagawa Estuary, the lack of level land not only posed a significant obstacle to development of the castletown, but also hampered the development of Edo into metropolis.

sen.j: そこで徳川氏は、まず江戸城の大手門から隅田川まで道三堀を穿ち、そこから出た土で日比谷入江の埋め立てを開始した。
sen.e: Frist of all, the Tokugawa clan dug a moat (called Dosan Moat) from the Ote-mon Gate of the Edo Castle to Sumida-gawa River and redeemed Hibiya cove using the dug-out soils.

In response to this issue, Tokugawa dug the Dosan moat stretching from the Ote-mon Gate of Edo Castle to Sumida-gawa (river), and initiated the reclamation of Hibiya inlet using the earth from the prior previous moat construction.

In response to this issue, Tokugawa dug the Dosan moat stretching from the Ote-mon Gate of Edo Castle to Sumida-gawa (river), and initiated the reclamation of Hibiya inlet using the earth from the prior previous moat construction.

sen.j: 道三堀は墨田川河口から江戸城の傍まで、城の建造に必要な木材や石材を搬入するために活用され、道三堀の左右に舟町が形成された。
sen.e: The Dosan Moat was used to convey timbers and stones from the estuary of Sumida-gawa River up to the Edo Castle for reconstruction of the Castle, and funamachi (ship towns) were also built on the banks of Dosan Canal.

The Dosan canal was used to transport timber and stone building materials required for the construction of the castle from the Sumidagawa estuary up to the Edo Castle, and a funamachi (riverine port town) was built one both banks of the canal.

The Dosan canal was used to transport timber and stone building materials required for the construction of the castle from the Sumidagawa estuary up to the Edo Castle, and a funamachi (riverine port town) was built one both banks of the canal.

sen.j: また、元からあった平地である今の常盤橋門外から日本橋の北に最初の町人地が設定された（この時と時期を同じくして平川の日比谷入江から江戸前島を貫通する流路変更が行われたと思われる）。
sen.e: Also, on the flatland stretching from the current Tokiwabashi Gate to the north of Nihon-bashi Bridge, the first choninchi (area where merchants and artisans lived) was set up (to coincide with the construction of choninchi, it is believed that the route of Hira-kawa River was diverted so that it passed through Edo Maejima from Hibiya cove).

Additionally, the first townspeople (residential) zone was designated north of the outside of the Tokiwa-bashi Gate and Nihon-bashi bridge (an area designated for the habitation of merchants and artisans) (It is thought that the course of Hira-kawa River stretching towards Hibiya inlet was diverted to pass through Edo Maejima.)

Additionally, the first townspeople (residential) zone was designated north of the outside of the Tokiwa-bashi Gate and Nihon-bashi bridge (an area designated for the habitation of merchants and artisans) (It is thought that the course of Hira-kawa River stretching towards Hibiya inlet was diverted to pass through Edo Maejima.)

sen.j: これが江戸本町、今の日本銀行本店や三越本店がある一帯である。
sen.e: This is the area called Edo Honmachi, presently where the central branch of the Bank of Japan and the main store of Mitsukoshi stand.
This area known as Edo Honmachi encompassed the area where the central branch of the Bank of Japan and the main store of Mitsukoshi currently stand.
This area known as Edo Honmachi encompassed the area where the central branch of the Bank of Japan and the main store of Mitsukoshi currently stand.

sen.j: さらに元からあった周辺集落である南の芝 (東京都港区)、北の浅草や西の赤坂、牛込、麹町にも町屋が発展した。
sen.e: Furthermore, machiya (merchant houses) were also built in the villages, such as Shiba in the south (Minato Ward), Asakusa in the north and Akasaka, Ushigome and Kojimmachi in the west.
Furthermore, machiya (merchant houses) were also built in the villages such as Shiba in the south (Minato Ward), Asakusa in the north, and Akasaka, Ushigome and Kojimachi in the west.
Furthermore, machiya (merchant houses) were also built in the villages such as Shiba in the south (Minato Ward), Asakusa in the north, and Akasaka, Ushigome and Kojimachi in the west.

sen.j: この頃の江戸の姿を伝える地図としては『別本慶長江戸図』が知られている。
sen.e: The most famous map of Edo in this period is "Beppon Keicho Edo zu".
The most famous map of Edo in this period isThe "Beppon Keicho Edo zu,"is known as a map that reveals Edo as it was.
The most famous map of Edo in this period isThe "Beppon Keicho Edo zu,"is known as a map that reveals Edo as it was.

sen.j: 江戸は「の」の字形に設計されたことが一般の城下町と比べて特異であるといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that Edo was structured in the form of 'の' (a letter of Kana syllable, pronounced 'no'), a quite unique design, compared to other castle towns.
It is said that Edo was structured in the form of 'の' (a letter of Kana syllable, pronounced 'no'), a quite unique design, compared to other castle towns.
sen.cmt: It is often stated that Edo's unique "no" (character "no") shaped layout distinguishes it from other castle towns.
sen.e: It is said that Edo was structured in the form of 'の' (a letter of Kana syllable, pronounced 'no'), a quite unique design, compared to other castle towns.

sen.j: つまり、江戸城の本城は大手門から和田倉門、馬場先門、桜田門の内側にある本丸、二の丸、西の丸などの内郭に将軍、次期将軍となる将軍の世子、先代の将軍である大御所が住む御殿が造られ、その西にあたる半蔵門内の吹上に将軍の親族である徳川御三家の屋敷が置かれた。
sen.e: In this structure, palaces of shogun, his heir and ogosho (ex-shogun) were positioned in the center compound of the Edo Castle (Honmaru, Ninomaru and Nishinomaru) surrounded by three gates (Ote-mon Gate, Wadakura-mon Gate, Babasaki-mon Gate and Sakurada-mon Gate), and residences of Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of the Tokugawa family) were placed in Fukiage in the west of the Castle, guarded by the Hanzo-mon Gate.

The palaces of shogun, his heir and ogosho (ex-shogun) were constructed the central castle compound of the Edo Castle within the Honmaru, Ninomaru and Nishinomaru interior castle that were enclosed by the Ote-mon, Wadakura-mon, Babasaki-mon, and Sakurada-mon cates, and the residences of Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of the Tokugawa family) were reserved west of the Castle and behind Hanzo-mon gate Gate.

The palaces of shogun, his heir and ogosho (ex-shogun) were constructed the central castle compound of the Edo Castle within the Honmaru, Ninomaru and Nishinomaru interior castle that were enclosed by the Ote-mon, Wadakura-mon, Babasaki-mon, and Sakurada-mon cates, and the residences of Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of the Tokugawa family) were reserved west of the Castle and behind Hanzo-mon gate Gate.

sen.j: 内城の堀の外は東の大手門下から和田倉門外に譜代大名の屋敷、南の桜田門の外に外様大名の屋敷と定められ、西の半蔵門外から一ツ橋門、神田橋門外に至る台地に旗本・御家人が住まわされ、さらに武家屋敷地や大名屋敷地の東、常盤橋・呉服橋・鍛冶橋・数寄屋橋から隅田川、江戸湾に至るまでの日比谷埋立地方面に町人地が広げられた。
sen.e: Outside of the inner moats, residences of fudai daimyo (hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) were built in the eastern area where the Ote-mon Gate and the Wadakura-mon Gate stretched, residences of tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lord) were also built in the south of the Castle, outside the Sakurada-mon Gate, and ones of Hatamoto and Gokenin (shogun retainers) on the western hillside stretching from the Hanzo-mon Gate, Hitotsubashi-mon Gate to Kandabashi-mon Gate, while in the east of samurai and daimyo residences, choninchi was expanded into the reclaimed lands in the Hibiya area that covered Tokiwa-bashi Bridge, Gofuku-bashi Bridge, Kaji-bashi Bridge, Sukiya-bashi Bridge, Sumida-gawa River and the Edo Bay.

Residences of fudai daimyo (hereditary vassals to the Tokugawa clan) were built on the western outskirts of the interior castle moat between the Oote-mon and Wadakura-mon gates, an area south of the Sakurada-mon gate was designated the residence of the tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lord), and Hatamoto and Gokenin (shogunal retainers) were housed on a hillside stretching between the outskirts of the western Hanzo-mon gate to Hitotsubashi-mon and Kandabashi-mon gates; choninchi (residential and commercial areas for townspeople) the reclaimed lands in Hibiya stretched between Tokiwa-bashi Bridge, Gofuku-bashi Bridge, Kaji-bashi Bridge, Sukiya-bashi Bridge, Sumida-gawa River and the Edo Bay.

Residences of fudai daimyo (hereditary vassals to the Tokugawa clan) were built on the western outskirts of the interior castle moat between the Oote-mon and Wadakura-mon gates, an area south of the Sakurada-mon gate was designated the residence of the tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lord), and Hatamoto and Gokenin (shogunal retainers) were housed on a hillside stretching between the outskirts of the western Hanzo-mon gate to Hitotsubashi-mon and Kandabashi-mon gates; choninchi (residential and commercial areas for townspeople) the reclaimed lands in Hibiya stretched between Tokiwa-bashi Bridge, Gofuku-bashi Bridge, Kaji-bashi Bridge, Sukiya-bashi Bridge, Sumida-gawa River and the Edo Bay.

sen.j: これを地図で見るとちょうど大手門から数寄屋橋に至るまでの「の」の字の堀の内外に渦巻き上に将軍・親藩・譜代・外様大名・旗本御家人・町人が配置されている形になる。
sen.e: As shown on the map, shogun, shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives), fudai daimyo, tozama daimyo, hatamoto and townspeople were positioned inside and outside the moats, in the area stretching from Ote-mon Gate to Sukiya-bashi Bridge, in a spiral shape of 'の' (no).

The layout of Edo is evident on the map as the shogunal, shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives), fudai daimyo, tozama daimyo, hatamoto and townspeople are positioned inside and outside a "の" shaped moat stretching from Ote-mon Gate to Sukiya-bashi Bridge.

The layout of Edo is evident on the map as the shogunal, shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives), fudai daimyo, tozama daimyo, hatamoto and townspeople are positioned inside and outside a "の" shaped moat stretching from Ote-mon Gate to Sukiya-bashi Bridge.

sen.j: 巻き貝が殻を大きくするように、渦巻き型に柔軟に拡大できる構造を取ったことが、江戸の拡大を手助けした。
sen.e: As a snail's shell grows bigger and bigger, Edo grew into a metropolis by adopting a city structure of a spiral shape to expand flexibly.
Just as a snail expands its shell as it grows, the adoption of a spiral structure facilitated the flexible expansion of Edo.
Just as a snail expands its shell as it grows, the adoption of a spiral structure facilitated the flexible expansion of Edo.

sen.j: 家康の死後、二代将軍徳川秀忠は、江戸の北東の守りを確保するため、小石川門の西から南に流れていた平川をまっすぐ東に通す改修を行った。
sen.e: After the death of Ieyasu, the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, improved the channel of Hira-kawa River, which originally run from the west of the Koishigawa-mon Gate to the south, so that it run straight from the west to the east in order to reinforce the defense of northeastern Edo.

After the death of Ieyasu, the second shogun, TOKUGAWA Hidetada ordered the the diversion of the Hirakawa River, which flowed southwards from west side of the Koishigawa-mon gate, to flow eastwards to secure a defensive barrier for Northeastern Edo..

After the death of Ieyasu, the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA ordered the the diversion of the Hirakawa River, which flowed southwards from west side of the Koishigawa-mon gate, to flow eastwards to secure a defensive barrier for Northeastern Edo..
sen.cmt: 個人名、姓名の順に修正しました。

sen.j: 今の水道橋から万世橋（秋葉原）の間は本郷から駿河台まで伸びる神田台地があったためこれを掘り割って人口の谷を造って通し、そこから西は元から神田台地から隅田川に流れていた中川の流路を転用し、浅草橋を通って隅田川に流れるようにした。
sen.e: The Kanda Plain, which stretched from Hongo to Surugadai (present-day, Suido-bashi Bridge to Mansei-bashi Bridge [Akihabara]), was dug to create an artificial valley so that the Hira-kawa River run through the valley, joined Naka-gawa River in the west (which originated in the Kanda Plain and poured into Sumida-gawa River) and run under Asakusa-bashi Bridge to pour into Sumida-gawa River.

An artificial valley was dug between the Kanda Plateau that stretched from Hongo to Surugadai (The areas between present-day Suido-bashi and Mansei-bashi bridges [Akihabara]) to dug to create an artificial valley so that the Hira-kawa River run through the valley, joined Naka-gawa River in the west (which originated in the Kanda Plain and poured into Sumida-gawa River) and run under Asakusa-bashi Bridge to pour into Sumida-gawa River.

An artificial valley was dug between the Kanda Plateau that stretched from Hongo to Surugadai (The areas between present-day Suido-bashi and Mansei-bashi bridges [Akihabara]) to dug to create an artificial valley so that the Hira-kawa River run through the valley, joined Naka-gawa River in the west (which originated in the Kanda Plain and poured into Sumida-gawa River) and run under Asakusa-bashi Bridge to pour into Sumida-gawa River.

sen.j: これが江戸城の北の外堀である神田川 (東京都)である。
sen.e: The river was renamed Kanda-gawa River and served as an outer northern moat of the Edo Castle.
This would later become the Kanda-gawa River, which became the outer northern moat of the Edo Castle.
This would later become the Kanda-gawa River, which became the outer northern moat of the Edo Castle.

sen.j: この工事によって平川下流であった一ツ橋、神田橋、日本橋を経て隅田川に至る川筋は神田川（平川）から切り離され、江戸城の堀となった。
sen.e: After the channel improvement work, one downstream channel of Hira-kawa River, running under Hitotsu-bashi Bridge, Kanda-bashi Bridge and Nihon-bashi Bridge and poured to Sumida-gawa River, was detached from Kanda-gawa River (former Hira-kawa River) and rebuilt as a moat of the Edo Castle.

Through this channel improvement work, the lower reaches of the Hira-kawa River that flowed into Sumida-gawa River after passing through Hitotsu-bashi Bridge, Kanda-bashi Bridge, and Nihon-bashi Bridge, was cut-off from the Kanda-gawa River (former Hira-kawa River) and became the Edo Castle moat.

Through this channel improvement work, the lower reaches of the Hira-kawa River that flowed into Sumida-gawa River after passing through Hitotsu-bashi Bridge, Kanda-bashi Bridge, and Nihon-bashi Bridge, was cut-off from the Kanda-gawa River (former Hira-kawa River) and became the Edo Castle moat.

sen.j: この堀が再び神田川に接続され、神田川支流の日本橋川となるのは明治時代のことである。
sen.e: In the Meiji Period, this moat was reconnected to Kanda-gawa River and renamed Nihon-bashi River as a branch of Kanda-gawa River.
It was not until the Meiji Period that this moat was reconnected to Kanda-gawa River and renamed Nihon-bashi River-- a branch of the Kanda-gawa River.
It was not until the Meiji Period that this moat was reconnected to Kanda-gawa River and renamed Nihon-bashi River-- a branch of the Kanda-gawa River.

sen.j: 更に3代将軍徳川家光はこれまで手薄で残されてきた城の西部外郭を固めることにし、溜池や神田川に注ぎ込む小川の谷筋を利用して溜池から赤坂、四ッ谷、市ヶ谷を経て牛込に至り、神田川に接する外堀を造らせた。
sen.e: Also, the third shogun, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, started reinforcing the outer compound in the west which was left untouched, and built an outer moat by using the valleys of streams that run into a reservoir and Kanda-gawa River, and the constructed moat stretched from the reservoir through Akasaka, Yotsuya, Ichigaya to Ushigome and poured into Kanda-gawa River.

Moreover, the third shogun, TOKUGAWA Iemitsu decided to reinforce the castle's western exterior enclosure, which was left untouched, and built an outer moat using the reservoirs and streams that coursed through Akasaka, Yotsuya, Ichigaya to Ushigome before flowing into Kanda-gawa River.

Moreover, the third shogun, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA decided to reinforce the castle's western exterior enclosure, which was left untouched, and built an outer moat using the reservoirs and streams that coursed through Akasaka, Yotsuya, Ichigaya to Ushigome before flowing into Kanda-gawa River.
sen.cmt: 個人名、姓名の順に修正しました。

sen.j: 全国の外様大名を大動員して行われた外堀工事は1636年に竣工し、ここに御成門から浅草橋門に至る江戸城の「の」の字の外側の部分が完成した。
sen.e: This construction work finished in 1636 with tozama daimyo throughout the nation mobilized, meaning that the outer portion of 'の', equivalent to the area from Onari-mon Gate to Asakusabashi-mon Gate, was also completed.

The construction of the moat, which required a massive mobilization on the part of tozama daimyo, was finished in 1636, and marked the completion of a outer portion of the spiral-shaped urban layout that spanned the Onari-mon and Asakusabashi-mon gates.

The construction of the moat, which required a massive mobilization on the part of tozama daimyo, was finished in 1636, and marked the completion of a outer portion of the spiral-shaped urban layout that spanned the Onari-mon and Asakusabashi-mon gates.

sen.j: 城下町において武家地、町人地とならぶ要素は寺社地であるが、江戸では寺社の配置に風水の思想が重視されたという。
sen.e: Jisha-chi (lands for temples and shrines) was an important constituent of a castle town along with Bukechi (lands for samurai) and Choninchi (lands for townspeople), and it is said that in Edo, Feng Shui played an important role in the construction of temples and shrines.

Among the elements that constitute castletowns, the significance of jisha-chi (lands for temples and shrines) was on par with the bukechi (lands for samurai) and Choninchi (lands for townspeople), but it is said that geomancy also dicated the location of temples and shrines during the Edo period.

Among the elements that constitute castletowns, the significance of jisha-chi (lands for temples and shrines) was on par with the bukechi (lands for samurai) and Choninchi (lands for townspeople), but it is said that geomancy also dicated the location of temples and shrines during the Edo period.

sen.j: そもそも江戸城が徳川氏の城に選ばれた理由の一因には、江戸の地が当初は北の玄武は麹町台地、東の青龍は神田川 (東京都)、南の朱雀は日比谷入江、西の白虎は東海道、江戸の拡大後は、玄武に本郷 (文京区)台地、青龍に大川（隅田川）、朱雀に江戸湾、白虎に甲州街道と四神相応に則っている点とされる。
sen.e: One reason why the Tokugawa clan chose the Edo Castle as its main residence is that Edo was believed to have Shijin-soo (an ideal topography for the four Taoist gods, with a river in the east, a broad avenue in the west, a basin in the south, and a hill in the north); it was considered that in the original Edo town, Genbu (god of water) resided in Kojimachi highland in the north of the Castle, Seiryu (Blue Dragon) in Kanda-gawa River in the east, Suzaku (red Chinese phoenix) in Hibiya cove in the south, and Byakko (White Tiger) in To-kaido Road in the west, and after the expansion of Edo, Genbu was placed in Hongo highland (Bunkyo Ward), Seiryu in O-kawa River (Sumida-gawa River), Suzaku in Edo bay and Byakko in Koshu-kaido Road.

One reason why the Tokugawa clan chose the Edo Castle as its primary residence was that the geographical location of Edo was ideally aligned with shijin-soo philosopy that sought geographic analogs of the four Daoist gods Genbu (God of Water), Suzaku (Red Phoenix), Seiryu (Blue Dragon) and Byakko (White Tiger) respectively manifest in the geographic forms of hills in the north, a basin to the south, a river in the east, and a broad avenue to the west; Such geographic analogs of geomantic ideals were manifest in the Kojimachi plateau to the north, the Hibiya Inlet to the south, the Kanda-gawa River in the east, and the Tokai-do road to the west; the geographic analogs of geomantic ideals were respectively reconfigured to the Hongo highlands (Bunkyo Ward), Edo bay, O-kawa River (Sumida-gawa River), and the Koshu-kaido Road in response to the growth of Edo.
sen.cmt: Significant stylistic changes (Elements rearranged to a north, south, east, and west order to simplify the passage.)
sen.e: One reason why the Tokugawa clan chose the Edo Castle as its primary residence was that the geographical location of Edo was ideally aligned with shijin-soo philosopy that sought geographic analogs of the four Daoist gods Genbu (God of Water), Suzaku (Red Phoenix), Seiryu (Blue Dragon) and Byakko (White Tiger) respectively manifest in the geographic forms of hills in the north, a basin to the south, a river in the east, and a broad avenue to the west; Such geographic analogs of geomantic ideals were manifest in the Kojimachi plateau to the north, the Hibiya Inlet to the south, the Kanda-gawa River in the east, and the Tokai-do road to the west; the geographic analogs of geomantic ideals were respectively reconfigured to the Hongo highlands (Bunkyo Ward), Edo bay, O-kawa River (Sumida-gawa River), and the Koshu-kaido Road in response to the growth of Edo.

sen.j: 関東の独立を掲げた武将で、代表的な怨霊でもある平将門を祭る神田明神は、大手門前（現在の首塚周辺）から、江戸城の鬼門にあたる駿河台へと移され、江戸惣鎮守として奉られた。
sen.e: Kanda Myojin-Shine which enshrined TAIRA no Masakado, a samurai who aimed at the independence of the Kanto region and who later turned into the most famous vengeful ghost, was moved from Ote-mon Gate (present-day, the area around Kubi-zuka) to Surugadai in the northeast of the Edo Castle, the direction called Kimon (an unlucky direction in Onmyodo [yin-yang philosophy]), and Masakado was enshrined as the Shinto deity of Edo there.

Kanda Myojin-Shine which enshrined TAIRA no Masakado, a renown samurai who sought the independence of the Kanto region and who said to have later turned into a vengeful ghost, was relocated from Ote-mon Gate (The area surrounding the present day Kubi-zuka [Mound of Heads]) to Surugadai to the northeast of Edo Castle which was known as a kimon (Literally translated as the "demons gate," which signified an inauspicious direction in Onmyodo [yin-yang philosophy]), and enshrined their as a Shinto deity and protector of Edo.

Kanda Myojin-Shine which enshrined TAIRA no Masakado, a renown samurai who sought the independence of the Kanto region and who said to have later turned into a vengeful ghost, was relocated from Ote-mon Gate (The area surrounding the present day Kubi-zuka [Mound of Heads]) to Surugadai to the northeast of Edo Castle which was known as a kimon (Literally translated as the "demons gate," which signified an inauspicious direction in Onmyodo [yin-yang philosophy]), and enshrined their as a Shinto deity and protector of Edo.

sen.j: また、江戸城の建設にともなって城内にあった山王権現（現在の日枝神社）は裏鬼門である赤坂へと移される。
sen.e: Also, during the reconstruction of the Edo Castle, Sanno Gongen (present-day, Hie-jinja Shrine) was moved from the Castle compound to Akasaka in the southwest, the direction called Urakimon, another unlucky direction in Onmyodo.

Additionally, the Sanno Gongen (present-day Hie-jinja Shrine) was relocated from the castle compound to Akasaka in the southwest where the Urakimon (literally translated as the back-demons' gate) during the reconstruction of Edo Castle.

Additionally, the Sanno Gongen (present-day Hie-jinja Shrine) was relocated from the castle compound to Akasaka in the southwest where the Urakimon (literally translated as the back-demons' gate) during the reconstruction of Edo Castle.

sen.j: 更に、家康の帰依していた天台宗の僧天海が江戸城の鬼門にあたる上野忍岡を拝領、京都の鬼門封じである比叡山に倣って堂塔を建設し、1625年に寛永寺を開山した。
sen.e: Moreover, the monk of Tendai sect, Tenkai, whom Ieyasu strongly trusted, was granted the land called Ueno-Shinobugaoka in the Kimon direction, where he elected temple buildings and founded Kanei-ji Temple in 1625 to purify Kimon by following the method of Mt. Hiei in Kyoto.

Moreover, Ieyasu entrusted land in Ueno-Shinobugaoka which faced the kimon to the Tenda sect monk Tenkai, who erected a stupa in the likeness of Mt. Hiei which contains the demon's gate (kimon) and founded the Kanei-ji Temple in 1625.

Moreover, Ieyasu entrusted land in Ueno-Shinobugaoka which faced the kimon to the Tenda sect monk Tenkai, who erected a stupa in the likeness of Mt. Hiei which contains the demon's gate (kimon) and founded the Kanei-ji Temple in 1625.

sen.j: 寛永寺の山号は東叡山、すなわち東の比叡山を意味しており、寺号は延暦寺と同じように建立時の年号から取られている。
sen.e: The sango (the mountain name given to each temple) of Kanei-ji Temple was To-eizan, meaning Mt. Hiei-zan in the east, and the jigo (temple name) was named after the era in which the temple was elected, as was Enryaku-ji Temple (in Mt. Hiei) which was built in the Enryaku era.

The "sango" (A name bestowed to each temple.) for Kanei-ji Temple was Toei-zan, which meant the Mt. Hiei of the east; and its "jigo" (temple name) was the era in which the temple was erected-- akin to Enryaku-ji Temple (in Mt. Hiei) which was built in the Enryaku era.

The "sango" (A name bestowed to each temple.) for Kanei-ji Temple was Toei-zan, which meant the Mt. Hiei of the east; and its "jigo" (temple name) was the era in which the temple was erected-- akin to Enryaku-ji Temple (in Mt. Hiei) which was built in the Enryaku era.

sen.j: 江戸は海辺を埋め立てて作られた町のため、井戸を掘っても真水を十分に得ることができず、水の確保が問題となる。
sen.e: As Edo was expanded on the redeemed seashore, wells in Edo did not give enough fresh water, and therefore, securing fresh water became a challenge for the Edo bakufu.
Water security became an issue for Edo as it grew, since it was a town built over reclaimed shoreline, and digging wells alone could not secure ample fresh water.
Water security became an issue for Edo as it grew, since it was a town built over reclaimed shoreline, and digging wells alone could not secure ample fresh water.

sen.j: そこで、赤坂に元からあった溜池が活用されると共に、井の頭池を水源とする神田上水が造られた。
sen.e: As a solution, not only a reservoir in Akasaka was utilized, but also the Kanda Josui Water Supply was built to bring water from Inokashira Pond.
As a solution, the Kanda Waterworks that was fed by water from from Inokashira Pond, and a prexisting reservoir in Akasaka were used to supply water to the city.
As a solution, the Kanda Waterworks that was fed by water from from Inokashira Pond, and a prexisting reservoir in Akasaka were used to supply water to the city.

sen.j: やがて江戸の人口が増えて来るとこれだけでは供給し切れなくなり、水不足が深刻になって来た。
sen.e: As a population of Edo grew larger, these two systems could not supply enough water to the people, and water shortage became a serious issue.
As a population of Edo grew larger, these two systems could no longer supply enough water to the populace, and the city faced serious water shortages.
As a population of Edo grew larger, these two systems could no longer supply enough water to the populace, and the city faced serious water shortages.

sen.j: このために造られた水道が1653年完成の玉川上水である。
sen.e: To combat the problem, another water supply, the Tamagawa Josui Water Supply, was built in 1653.
The Tamagawa Waterworks was built in 1653 to alleviate such shortages.
The Tamagawa Waterworks was built in 1653 to alleviate such shortages.

sen.j: 水道は江戸っ子の自慢の物の一つで、「水道の水を産湯に使い」などと言う言葉がよく使われる。
sen.e: This water supply was one of what Edo people were very proud of, and they often said that 'I used tap water to give my baby its first bath'.
The water works were a source of pride for the peoploe of Edo, and they are noted as saying that "[they] used tap water to give [their] newborns [their] first bath."
The water works were a source of pride for the peoploe of Edo, and they are noted as saying that "[they] used tap water to give [their] newborns [their] first bath."

sen.j: 1640年には江戸城の工事が最終的に完成し、江戸の都市建設はひとつの終着点に達した。
sen.e: In 1640, the reconstruction of the Edo Castle was completed, and the urbanization of the Edo town also ended with a fair amount of achievement.
The reconstruction of the Edo Castle was completed in 1640, marking one end point in the urban development of Edo.
The reconstruction of the Edo Castle was completed in 1640, marking one end point in the urban development of Edo.

sen.j: しかし、1657年に明暦の大火が起こると江戸の町は大部分が焼亡し、江戸城天守も炎上してしまった。
sen.e: However, the Great Fire of Meireki occurred in 1657, burning down most of Edo, and the tenshu (tower) of the Edo Castel burst into flames as well.
However, most of the city including the tenshu (tower) of Edo Castle was destroyed during the Great Fire of Meireki in 1657.
However, most of the city including the tenshu (tower) of Edo Castle was destroyed during the Great Fire of Meireki in 1657.

sen.j: 幕府はこれ以降、火事をできるだけ妨げられるよう都市計画を変更することになった。
sen.e: After the fire, bakufu changed its urbanization plan, placing more focus on prevention of fires.
After the fire, the bakufu revised its urban planning policies to minimize the risk of fire hazards.
After the fire, the bakufu revised its urban planning policies to minimize the risk of fire hazards.

sen.j: これまで吹上にあった御三家の屋敷が半蔵門外の紀尾井町に移されるなど大名屋敷の配置換えが行われ、類焼を防ぐための火除地として十分な広さの空き地や庭園が設けられた。
sen.e: Residences of daimyo were relocated, the mansions of Tokugawa gosanke in Fukiage were also moved to Kioi-cho Town outside the Manzo-mon Gate, and large empty lots and gardens were also set up to prevent spreads of fires into neighboring areas.

Daimyo residences such as as those of the Tokugawa gosanke in Fukiage were relocated to Kioi-cho Town outside the Manzo-mon Gate, and large empty lots and gardens were established to prevent fires from spreading to neighboring areas.

Daimyo residences such as as those of the Tokugawa gosanke in Fukiage were relocated to Kioi-cho Town outside the Manzo-mon Gate, and large empty lots and gardens were established to prevent fires from spreading to neighboring areas.

sen.j: 大名屋敷が再建され、参勤交代のために多くの武士が滞在するようになると、彼らの生活を支えるため江戸の町は急速に復興するが、もはや外堀内の江戸の町は狭すぎる状態だった。
sen.e: As Daimyo residences were being reconstructed and an increased number of samurai were moving in for the Sankinkotai system, the town of Edo revived quickly to support their lives, but in practical terms, the Edo town inside the outer moat was too small to accommodate all these people.

The town of Edo recovered as daimyo reconstructed their residences and as an ever increasing number of samurai migrated to the city in accordance to the Sankinkotai system, the town of Edo rapidly recovered to support their needs; but in practical terms, the town of Edo could not longer be contained within its outer moat.

The town of Edo recovered as daimyo reconstructed their residences and as an ever increasing number of samurai migrated to the city in accordance to the Sankinkotai system, the town of Edo rapidly recovered to support their needs; but in practical terms, the town of Edo could not longer be contained within its outer moat.

sen.j: こうして江戸の町の拡大が始まり、隅田川の対岸、深川・永代島まで都市化が進んでいった。
sen.e: The surge in population made the town expand even more, and Fukagawa and Eitaijima, which were located in the opposite shore of Sumida-gawa River, were also urbanized.
It is within this context that the town of Edo began to expand, urbanization spread beyond the banks of the Sumida-gawa and Fukagawa-rivers, and advanced to Eitai-jima.
It is within this context that the town of Edo began to expand, urbanization spread beyond the banks of the Sumida-gawa and Fukagawa-rivers, and advanced to Eitai-jima.

sen.j: 南・西・北にも都市化の波は及び、外延部の上野 (台東区)、浅草が盛り場として発展、さらに外側には吉原遊郭が置かれていた。
sen.e: The urbanization also began in the south, west and north of Edo, and Ueno (Taito Ward) and Asakusa, both on the edge of Edo, were developed into an amusement area surrounded by Yoshihara yukaku (red-light district).

The urbanization also began in the south, west and north of Edo, and Ueno (Taito Ward) and Asakusa on the peripheries of Edo developed into amusement districts, and the Yoshiwara yukaku (red-light district) became located outside of this area.

The urbanization also began in the south, west and north of Edo, and Ueno (Taito Ward) and Asakusa on the peripheries of Edo developed into amusement districts, and the Yoshiwara yukaku (red-light district) became located outside of this area.
